dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mid-morning crush at the students’ mailboxes, a noisy with combination locks being spun open and slammed shut, racket blunted by the steady march of delinquent students worn marble steps leading to the Dean’s and Bursar’s offi However, downstairs there is the happy activity of the mid-morning break, clusters of gossipers, the excitement plans being hatched. Nearby hangs a bulletin board, decor with plastic turkeys. Standing in front of it, a good-loo kid whose cut-rate haircut and J.c. Penney coat-and-tie d fit in with the Preppie platoons. His name is CHARLIE SIM 17, and he is scanning the sparse entries under "Student Jobs, Thanksgiving Weekend".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A_new maroon Jaguar pulls into the #1 parking spot. Out s DEAN TRASK, an avuncular man in his 50’s, the obligatory schoolmaster’s cozy bow tie and blue blazer, however the bears more the flinty expression of a labor negotiator or baseball front office man. Observing Trask from in front of the Administration Build another group of students, HARRY HAVEMEYER, 18, a born-to-the-purple prep school prince, GEORGE WILLIS, 17, Harry’s consort, and two aides of Harry’s, TRENT and JIMM

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Will you look at this?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it, they really gave it to hin. HARRY “ Now he’s a loser with a Jaguar. Dean Trask locks the car, gives it a last, cherishing loo heads for the Administration Building. Harry breaks off f his cohorts and angles across the yard to cut him off. é HARRY (contd) Dean Trask!

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Good morning, Havemeyer.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: What’s fabulous?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: That’s some piece of steel you got.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: You don’t think I deserve it? Harry holds the door open for Dean Trask as he enters the Administration Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry pursues Trask as he moves down the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: ...No sir, I think it’s great. Why should the head of Baird be putt-putting around in some junker? I think the Board of Trustees have had their first stroke of inspiration in some time.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Well thank you, Havemeyer, I’11 take that at face value. Leaving Harry behind, Trask enters his office where he is greeted by MRS. HUNSAKER, 55, his no-nonsense, New Englan secretary. She has four delinquents waiting in chairs in of her, their pink Dean’s slips balled up in sweaty palms Trask passes by. TRASK (contd) Good morning, Mrs. Hunsaker. (to the boys) What have we here, Murderers’ Row? He chuckles, delighted by his own turn of phrase, and ent inner office. Across the lobby Harry, withdrawing an envelope from his mailbox, meets up with his followers, Georges Trent and J who have joined him inside. Charlie is still at the bulle board.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What was all that?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C’mon, Harry --

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just saying hello. I always enjoy saying hello to Dean Trask. Harry opens the envelope, smiles. HARRY (contd) Sugarbush. Lift tickets and condo vouchers.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I thought we were going to Stowe.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sugarbush is Stowe, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell RINGS, the lobby starts to clear but Charlie conti to examine the job opportunities.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: ...We’re doing it right, Thanksgiving in Vermont, Christmas in Switzerland --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Christmas in Guh-staad is going to cost us --

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Staad, the ‘G’ is silent. George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ‘Staad.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Trent?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: ‘Staad. Harry turns back to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: So what about ‘Staad?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The ‘G’ may be silent but it costs three G’s to get there. I’11 have to talk to my father.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Better yet, why doesn’t my father talk to your father. : to class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind them, Charlie is having difficulty concentrating o listings as the snobbish, but good-natured, dispute conti The bell rings again, the lobby empties as students hurry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie bumps into Harry and George as they all squeeze o door, Jimmy and Trent following close behind as the group proceeds up a narrow path of the grassy quadrangle.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You going home this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Going home to fucking Idaho for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m from Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I meant fucking Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) How do you feel about skiing? In the mood for the white-bosomed slopes of Vermont?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Umm --

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: We got a deal going, kid. 20% off for my friends. My dad arranged it. Christmas in Switzerland --

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: *Staad -- HARRY . Gstaad. Dropping the ‘G’ is phony.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You just said everybody says ‘Staad.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Not if you’ve been there. to Charlie) Easter in Bermuda. Then, Kentucky Derby weekend. We could work you in, son.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How much are the \‘white-bosomed slopes of Vermont’?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Twelve hundred dollars. Included is a nine-course champagne Thanksgiving dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Twelve hundred dollars is a little rich for my blood, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: How short are you? Charlie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How short, Harry? So short it wouldn’t be worth the trouble for you and George to measure. But thanks for asking. Charlie breaks off, heads for class.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Harry) What’d you do that for? You know he’s on Aid --

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: On major holidays, Willis, it is customary for the lord of the manor to offer drippings to the poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Past the mill, across the river, above the noisy waterwor there is a blue-collar section, frame houses dark with so Charlie unfolds the squares of the piece of paper on whic copied down an address from the bulletin board. He checks number, heads up the sidewalk, rings the bell. KAREN ROSS answers, two children squeezed against her legs and pulli the seams of her jeans, FRANCINE, 4, blonde bangs, a misc smile and very dangerous, and WILLIE, 2, who does what Fr tells hin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rossi..? Karen looks Charlie up and down, he again checks his slip paper against the plastic dry wall numbers beside the doo Karen smiles ingratiatingly. CHARLIE (contd) ~ 16 Water Street -- ? I’m here about the weekend job?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen shows Charlie inside, Francine and Willie still cli to her.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Get out of the way, Francie --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCINE
dialogues.text: Has he got pimples? He hates pimples.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Pimples! Yay!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Shush. (to Charlie) I’m sorry, the School gave me your name but I’ve forgotten it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Charlie. Charlie Simms.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: How are you, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Right this way... Charlie follows Karen as she picks her way down a dark ha littered with toys and a stroller, past an adult work ben through a kitchen in deep activity with pots working on t stove. KAREN (contd) You’re available for the whole weekend?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not going home for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. *

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Good. She opens the back door, tired wooden steps lead down to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN (contd) -- They put him in a Veterans’ Home but he hated it. I told my dad we’d take him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen leads Charlie across the yard towards a small dark cottage, an unexpected outcropping in this cramped yard.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: -- Before you go in, do you mind my telling you a few things? Don’t ‘sir’ him, don’t light his cigars, and if he staggers a little when he stands up, don’t pay any attention. Charlie stops now, stares at the cottage’s dark windows. smiles, trying to displace Charlie’s sudden caution. KAREN (contd) Charlie, I can tell right away you’re the right person for the job. And Uncle Frank’s going to like you, too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going to be this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: We’re driving to Albany. Donny -- my husband -- he’s got family there. Karen reaches down for a cat who bounds out of a pet door bottom of the cottage’s entrance, she knocks, then calls KAREN (contd) Do you want Tommy in or out?! The briefest of silences, then a powerful VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE HIM OUT
dialogues.text: Charlie flinches. COLONEL SLADE (V.0.) (contd) He’s chasing that calico ginch from the tract houses! Karen, gently tossing the cat out into the yard, senses Charlie’s hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Down deep, the man is a lump of sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen gives Charlie a reassuring nod, and the gentlest of pushes. He enters the cottage, the door closes quietly be him. Through the silence, Charlie hears the burblings of children as Karen, heading back across the yard to her ho joined by Francine and Willie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCINE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He’s going to hate hin.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Pimples! INT. SLADE’S COTTAGE - DAY Semi-darkness but as the eyes become accustomed, objects to come into view. Charlie taps on the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t call me ‘sir!’

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I mean, mister -- sir --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What are you, a moron?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, mister, that is -- Charlie unfolds the squares of paper again, pores over it help, glances back at Karen’s house but she has disappear inside. CHARLIE (contd) Lieutenant, yes sir, Lieutenant -- ?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel! Twenty-six years on the line, no one ever busted me four grades before. Get in here, you idiot Charlie steps inside, through the crepuscular light the o objects Charlie can discern are some cat food and a bowl water at the bottom of a bulging bookcase. Coming into vi now, a blanket on the wall stitched in black, gray and go which reads "U.S.M.A. 1965", team and military unit photo a picture of the dismissed General MacArthur waving to th crowds on 5th Avenue from the back of an open car. Through the silence and darkness, a man becomes visible, in an armchair in the midst of this dormitory room/Bachel Officers Quarters. His name is FRANK SLADE, LT. COLONEL ( ret.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLADE (contd) Come closer, I want to get a better look at you. Charlie moves in closer and now, as Slade raises his head sniff the air, Charlie can make him out better. Slade is blind, still the man cuts a remarkable figure. I late-forties, he wears a coat and tie, a pair of jodhpur his chin is chiselled, his posture erect, not an ounce of his neck swiveling slightly as he brings Charlie into his both eyes staring blankly, crow’s feet around the corners them which prove, on closer examination, to be scars. SLADE (contd) How is your skin?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My skin, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: For chrissake!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- I don’t know, Mister --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Frank!’ Call me Frank! Or Mr. Slade. Or if you must, Colonel! Slade bangs the oversized silver oak leaf mounted on burn wood beside him, the plaque slashing into the table. He p the end of a cigar, reaches for a Zippo lighter and begin hit-and-miss business of lighting it. Charlie unconscious aids him with body English until the flame makes contact, Slade reaches for a mean bottle of whiskey beside him, sp the whiskey into a glass with such a vengeance that some dark liquid flies up onto his fingers, he waggles them at Charlie and the drops flicker onto Charlie’s nose. SLADE (contd) Simms, Charles, a Senior. You on Student Aid, Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I an.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: For ‘Student Aid’ read ‘crook.’ Your father peddles car telephones at a 300% markup and your mother works on heavy commission in a camera store. ~ (taps his ashes) Graduated to it from espresso machines. Charlie is at a loss.
SLADE (contd) What are you, dying of some wasting disease? .

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m right here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I know exactly where your body is. What I’m looking for 1s some indication of a brain. Too much football without your helmet? (cackles) Lyndon’s line on Jerry Ford. Deputy Debriefer, Paris Peace Talks, ‘68. Shave-tail, snagged a Silver Star, threw me into G-2. How old are you?
Slade sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Smells more like 18. (smiles lasciviously) Get down last night? The cat pops back through the pet door, crosses to his fo Slade senses him, fondly angles his head towards him. SLADE (contd) The old ass man didn’t quite get his ashes hauled. You can tell when he comes back hungry. Like a woman whose brains you’ve just fucked out and she asks you for a cigarette. Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Gresham, Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So what does your father do in Gresham, Oregon, count wood chips?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My stepfather and my mom run a convenience store.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE -
dialogues.text: 7-Eleven, Arco, Allsup’s?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s an independent.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What time they open?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hello. I don’t know, Mrs. Rossi -- I got the feeling I screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You couldn’t have.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- It was a bad interview.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That was no interview, Charlie, you’re it. You’re the only one who showed up. And you've got to take the job. He sleeps a lot, you can watch television, call your girlfriend, I promise you, an easy three hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t get an ‘easy’ feeling.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: His bark is worse than his bite. The man grows on you. By Sunday night, you'll be best friends. Charlie blinks. KAREN (contd) Charlie, please -- I want to get away with my husband for a few days -- and Uncle Frank won’t come with us. I could practically leave him alone -- I just feel better having someone around. Just in case. Please -- vu Donny turns around now from the bathtub, looks pleadingly Charlie... Karen does, too. Together, they wait for his decision. Finally, Charlie smiles reticently.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Mrs. Rossi. Sure. Karen smiles gratefully at Charlie, turns back to the bat Francine scoops some suds off her chest, throws them at C as he backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie exits, shoves his hands into his back pockets, re the whole, scruffy Rossi compound, now hurries off into t twilight and The Baird School.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Five AM.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Close?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: One AM.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hard workers, you got me all misty-eyed. So, what are you doing in this sparrow-fart town?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I attend Baird.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Attend’ Baird? I know you go to The Baird School. The point is how do you afford it, even with Student Aid plus the folks back home hustling the Corn Nuts?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I won a National Merit Scholarship. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hoo-rah. There is a tapping at a window pane of the door which ope the yard. Francine is there. SLADE (contd) Who’s that?! Francine rattles her fingers on the glass, sticks her ton out, makes a crazy face at Charlie. SLADE (contd) Is that that little piece of tail?! Get her out of here! He hurls a rubber mouse at the door, it slams against the window, falls to the floor, little bells ring gently. Sla tilts his head in the direction of Karen’s house. SLADE (contd) I can’t believe they’re my blood. The - IQ of sloths and the manners of banshees. A mechanic and a homemaker. He knows as much about cars as a beauty queen and she bakes cookies that taste like wing nuts. As for the tots, they’re twits. Did you say you had a skin condition, son? I like ny aides to be presentable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 12. Charlie feels his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I had a few zits, sir. (into himself) My roommate lent me his Clinique... he’s from Chestnut Hill and --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘The History of My Skin’ by Charles Simms. Are you patronizing me, Peewee? Giving me the old Prep School palaver? The Baird School. A bunch of runny-nosed snots in tweed jackets studying to be George Bush. CHARLIE ’ President Bush, I believe, went to Andover.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t sharpshoot me, punk. You’1l give me forty then you’ll give me forty more, then you'll pull K.P. The grease trap. I/’11 bury your nose in Enlisted Man’s crud until you don’t know which end is up! What do you want?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A job, Colonel Slade. I’m trying to make my plane fare home for Christmas. Slade drains his drink, starts the dangerous ceremony of lighting a fresh cigar, hits a button and country music P Charlie is in thrall. After a few moments, Slade shuts the music off.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Are you still hanging around, Poormouth? Convenience store, my ass. Hustling Jalapeno dips to the Appleseeds. Dis-missed! Charlie exits quickly, hurries across the yard to Karen’s INT. KAREN’S HOUSE - BATHROOM - DAY 10 Karen is bathing Francine, washing up Willie is DONNY, he husband, a blue-collar guy. .

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rossi -- ? Karen eagerly turns around from the tub to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Charlie, this is Donny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place quiet at night, a couple of lights burning in t Administration Building, the library, and the science lab INT. DEAN TRASK’S OFFICE - NIGHT 13 Dean Trask is working overtime, signing letters as Mrs. H prepares them in her outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is stamping out the books of the last student bef closing. The student is George. Charlie pauses over one o books.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This can’t go out, it’s on Reserve.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here’s the thing. I need it for tonight. Thanksgiving quiz with Big Shit Preston in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s why he put it on Reserve. We only got one copy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So I’ll heave it through the slot in the A.M. Chas, I got to do an all night, all frantic. Without this book, I’m dead. Charlie studies George.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If it’s not back by 7:30, it’s my ass --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I promise. Charlie shrugs, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. George grabs the book, Charlie reaches for a window pole desk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You headed back, I/’11 wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. Charlie closes the top of one of the great windows with a starts pulling down shades to half-mast. George stands by doesn’t help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 17 18 19 20 21 15. EXT. DEAN TRASK’S HOUSE - NIGHT The Dean’s maroon Jaguar is parked outside. Harry approac it stealthily, bends over the trunk, pops it open with a crowbar. Nearby, a concrete mixer from a small landscapin operation has been resting overnight beside a garden wall Jimmy jabs a bag of concrete mix with a spade, Trent pick the bag and heaves the contents into the mixer. Harry swi the mixer on, it THUMPS rhythmically. He picks up the noz of the mixer’s thick hose and jogs back to the car with i the first drops of concrete squeeze out.

dialogues.text: Charlie and George bounce down the marble steps leading t lobby of the building. INT. DEAN TRASK’S OFFICE - NIGHT Mrs. Hunsaker, all bundled up against the November chill, good night to Dean Trask as he finishes signing the day’s correspondence. EXT. DEAN’S HOUSE - NIGHT The trunk of Dean Trask’s Jaguar is open, the concrete mi churning, concrete pumping into the hose, Harry shooting high-pressure stream into the trunk of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and George emerge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ..-Hold on, got to get the door. George waits as Charlie locks up, turns out the last indo light, sets an outdoor light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hunsaker walks placidly across the silent quadrangle now her eyebrows knit at the SOUND of the concrete mixer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " George and Charlie heading along a path to the dormitor

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ..-God, can you wait to get out of . this dump?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where you going skiing again? Sugar Loaf?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bush, Chas, Bush, Sugarbush -- 15 16 17 18 19 20 21

dialogues.text: 22 23 16. George laughs, but now the SOUND of the concrete mixer ge attention. He and Charlie glance down towards the Dean’s see Harry, Trent and Jimmy busy around the concrete mixer EXT. DEAN’S HOUSE - NIGHT “22 Something makes the busy Harry look up, he sees the figur Mrs. Hunsaker approaching. Harry drops the hose, Jimmy sl the car trunk, Trent switches off the mixer and the three them take off. Sudden silence. From a distance, George and Charlie are observing the sce when Mrs. Hunsaker appears behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNSAKER
dialogues.text: Who was that? George looks at Charlie, Charlie looks at George. MRS. HUNSAKER (contd) Who were those boys? What were they doing?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNSAKER
dialogues.text: Charles?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ummm -- Mrs. Hunsaker now scrutinizes the exterior of the Dean’s put all is absolutely quiet. The silence is interrupted b 1970 Plymouth Valiant, in mint condition, pulling up at t at the end of the quadrangle path.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that your husband, Mrs. Hunsaker? Mrs. Hunsaker glances at her watch, checks around again b is still and she crosses the "yard" to her car. EXT. DEAN TRASK’S HOUSE - NEXT MORNING 23 Trask heads out into the brisk morning air, his pipe at a angle, is about to climb into his Jaguar, glances down, n it has a flat rear tire. He sighs, opens the door on the side, reaches in to pop the trunk release, then walks aro the back to get out the jack. But the trunk is filled wit solid concrete and now with a CRACK, the other rear tire way and the entire car tilts skywards as it settles back its rear axles. A hysterical, contemptuous ROAR from the hill overlooking Dean’s house, Trask looks up, half the student body has assembled to observe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piled high outside the door is weekend luggage, laundry b backpacks, hockey sticks taped to overnight valises. In t growded dining hall, Harry chats casually with George, Tr immy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ..-It’s the timing that I love. The morning of Thanksgiving weekend. What the hell’s he going to do now -~-

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: (to George) ..-You didn’t hear anything, you didn’t see anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: - And dammit, I didn’t get to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: You were too busy grinding for Preston’s quiz. If you’re not careful, George, you’re going to end up an Achiever.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I almost shat when the old bag --

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know a thing. Trent motions to Harry. They all fall silent as Charlie d through the dining hall doors just before they close, tak Closest seat available -- at Harry’s table. HARRY (contd) What about you, Oregon?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Did you see anything? Charlie glances casually at Harry, now at George, he is v aware of what is in the air. He reaches down the table fo serving bowl swimming with poached eggs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE -
dialogues.text: You get a Dean’s slip, Chas? George and Harry are studying Charlie, he chooses not to to George, but his eyes are on Harry as he answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 18. Charlie dips into the bowl, Harry stares with a mixture o wonder and contempt as Charlie slides a pair of watery eg a cold piece of toast. INT. DEAN TRASK’S OFFICE - MORNING "25 Dean Trask is at his window, looking down at the "yard" a maelstrom of students streaming out for the Thanksgiving as vans, buses and a few fancy private cars await them in street. Trask turns back from the window to George and Charlie wh seated in chairs in front of his desk. He closes his door

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms -- Mr. Willis -- Charlie comes to semi-attention in his chair, but George relaxed. TRASK (contd) Mrs. Hunsaker says both of you gentlemen were at a vantage point last night to observe who was responsible for this -- ah -- stunt. Silence. TRASK (contd) Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I really couldn’t tell you, sir. I thought it was weird the mixer was working at night but by the time I pulled focus, they were gone.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t say for sure.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Okay, for not sure?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh -- I don’t know -- uh... Dean Trask surveys Charlie and George, he takes his time he resumes.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: That automobile is not just a possession of mine. That automobile was presented to me by the Board of Trustees. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold smile 19. TRASK (contd) It is a symbol of the standard of excellence for which this school is known. And I will not have it tarnished.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The automobile? from Trask.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: The standard, Mr. Willis. He glances from George to Charlie. TRASK (contd) What is your position, Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: On what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: on preserving the reputation of Baird?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m for Baird.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Then who did it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t say for sure.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Do you know what a Class B felony is, Mr. Willis? George shakes his head "no." No response. TRASK (contd) Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: It’s a crime punishable by up to seven years in the State Penitentiary in Concord. Ever visited our prison in ~ Concord?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. He waits for silent. 20. TRASK (contd) It is not a pleasant place. That is where I am sending the instigators of this event and, unless you tell me fully and completely what happened, I’m going to see to it you end up there as well on whatever charges I can muster for not reporting the commission of the crime. Do I make myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Then what have you gentlemen got to say? TRASK (contd) very well. First thing Monday morning, when we're all over our big Thanksgiving weekend, I’m convening a special session of the Student-Faculty Disciplinary Committee. As this is a matter which concerns the whole school, the entire student body will be present. There will be no classes, no activities, nothing will transpire at this institution until that proceeding is concluded. And if at that time we are no further along than we are now, I will expel you both and turn this matter over to Andrew Runkle, the Attorney General of this state. We were in the same class at Dartmouth. Andy is a very good friend of mine. Charlie and George to speak, but they remain TRASK (contd) Mr. Willis, would you excuse us?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Pardon, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Wait outside with Mrs. Hunsaker. George nods anxiously, hurries out. Trask, silent for a m regards Charlie.
TRASK (contd) One of the few perks of this office is that I am empowered to handle certain matters on my own, as I see fit. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Good. The Dean of Admissions at Harvard and I have an arrangement. Along with the usual sheaf of applicants submitted by Baird of which virtually two thirds are guaranteed admittance, I add one name, somebody who is a standout and yet underprivileged. A student who cannot afford to pay the board and tuition in Cambridge. Do you know on whose behalf I’d drafted a memo this year?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: You. You, Mr. Simms. After a moment. TRASK (contd) Now can you tell me who did it? After another moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, sir, I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: You are aware of what’s at stake, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Harvard or jail. Trask studies him.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Take the weekend to think about it, Mr. Simms. Good morning. Charlie gets up and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George hurries down the steps with a shaken Charlie, and the Administration Building.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, ‘nothing’?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The same thing he said to both of us, he just said it over to me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He’s good-cop, bad-copping us. He knows I’m Old Guard, you’re fringe. He’s going to bear down on me, soft soap you. Did he try to soft soap you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uhh -- no.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’m getting a slight panic pulse from you, Charlie. Are you panicking?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're on scholarship, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: on scholarship from Oregon at Baird. You’re a long way from home, Chas. CHARLIE . What’s that got to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know how they do it out there but this is how we do it here. We stick together. It’s us against them, no matter what. We don’t tell our parents and we don’t cover our ass. Stonewall everybody and above ~ all never, never, leave any of us twisting in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s that got to do with my being on scholarship?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just trying to bring you up to speed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Give me a few hours to figure out the moves. Call me tonight in Vermont. We’ll be at the Sugarbush Lodge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess so. Charlie eases away, heads for one of the classroom buildi George keeps an eye on him until he disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos as Karen and Donny and the children get ready to de K-Mart luggage and shopping bags, the kids running sprint the kitchen on their tricycles as Donny tries to bundle t while Karen gives Charlie last-minute instructions.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: -- Try to keep him down to four drinks a day.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: If you can keep him down to forty, you’re doing good.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: We try to water them down a little. Do you know how to do that -~ ?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: (remonstrating) Honey --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. All his food is in the freezer. Vegetable soup, a nice fish casserole. There’s more than enough for both of you -- he’s not much of an eater. DONNY . It’s a long drive, honey --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Get the kids ready, I’11 be right out. Donny squeezes Charlie’s shoulder, gives him a smile of reassurance, goes to get the kids’ coats.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCINE
dialogues.text: Mommy, Mommy, don’t forget Uncle Frank’s walk --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yay, yay, his walk -- ! Francine and Willie ditch their trikes and launch into th version of a drunk -- Ben Blue/W.C. Fields/Foster Brooks into one, as rendered by two toddlers.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, you got to air him out a little every day. Charlie observes the kids’ performance anxiously. KAREN (contd) Why don’t you go back there and get oriented? I/’11 be out in a minute and give you telephone numbers and stuff. She turns back to button up the children, and Donny gathe their belongings as Charlie heads across the backyard to cottage. INT. SLADE’S COTTAGE - AFTERNOON 28 The SOUND of Slade on the telephone as Charlie enters. Ch glances around, the place is in transition, drawers open, various clothing items slung over chairs. Near a small refrigerator in an alcove, a huge mound of cat food and a bowl of water. Charlie pokes his head in the bedroom. Slade, aware of Ch immediately, waves him inside.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Is that you, Beautiful?...Yeah, we spoke yesterday. Did you have a glass of wine with lunch, you sound a little dusky? (chuckles dirtily) Charlie clears his throat politely. SLADE (contd) (irritated) Just a minute, Sweetheart... . (to Charlie) My dress blues, get them out, they’re in a garment bag in the closet. Check the top dresser drawer, take out the shoulder boards and affix them shoulders right and left ASAP.  25. Slade carries the phone into the sitting room as a bewild Charlie crosses into the bedroom. SLADE (contd) (phone) You know I’m not the kind of guy that likes to rush things but I am catching a 4 o’clock at Logan and I’m looking out my window and there’s no taxi in sight...Has Chet invested in a radio yet?...Well, get your driver on it and tell him to get a move on... (a seductive whisper) Some kind of body must go with that bedroom voice. One day I’m going to swing by and get a look at it. Charlie looks around the bedroom, the bed is stripped military-style, a pillow without a case rests on a blanke the foot of a sheetless mattress. Charlie blinks at the b the sudden WHACK of a cane against the door jamb. SLADE (contd) My Val-Pak’s underneath, put the boards on the blues and fold them in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We going someplace? i ) SLADE What business is it of yours? Charlie shrugs innocently. SLADE (contd) Don’t shrug, you imbecile. I’m blind. Save your body language for the bimbi. Now get out my gear! Slade sniffs the air. SLADE (contd) What time is it, it’s got to be about three and the goddamn Flintstones haven’t left yet. Charlie glances out the window.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Here comes Mrs. Rossi now. Slade reaches out and grabs Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I said good-bye to her twice, what has she got, separation anxiety? Cut her off at the door! :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 26. He pushes Charlie towards the door, keeping a hand on him stay oriented. Karen knocks gently, Charlie opens it. Sla calls to her over Charlie’s shoulder. SLADE (contd) Hi, honey! ‘Bye, honey! Karen reaches out, hands Charlie a folded piece of paper, provoking a wary Slade to crowd into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) This is where we’ll be -- In her rush, Karen takes a moment now. Purposefully, she up to kiss Slade and he, in return, searches her face wit hand. Charlie watches, entranced by the movement of Slade head which swivels like a performing seal as he scans Kar presence. KAREN (contd) I wish you were coming with us.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Maybe next time. Now Karen hurries away, Slade ducking back in the house a slightly forlorn Charlie remains in the doorway watching go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen strides quickly across the yard towards the car, wh Donny and the children are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Good luck, Charlie. Don’t let him drink too much! She climbs in the car, leans out the window. KAREN (contd) And no 900 numbers! He loves to talk dirty! _ The Rossis and their children drive away. Through the r window a disappearing Francine reprises her staggering dr routine for Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Get to work! INT. SLADE’S COTTAGE - DAY 30 Charlie hurries back inside, Slade is struggling with a p of luggage under his bed, Charlie bends to help him, pull a military bag, it is real pro, all polished leather and Slade straightens up and busies himself attending to his as, behind him, the straps on the bag confound Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What is it, the L-Buckles? Never in the Boy Scouts, sluggo?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Made tenderfoot.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Tenderfoot, my foot! A convenience store Mama’s boy! Give it to me. In order to guide Slade back to the bag on the bed, Charl takes Slade’s arm, but Slade slaps Charlie’s hand away violently. SLADE (contd) Touch me again and I’11 kill you, you little son-of-a-bitch. Charlie does a "hands off!" as if he’d touched a burning skillet. SLADE (contd) I touch you! Now go get my shoulder-boards. A chastened Charlie slides the bag over to Slade, in an i Slade has unfastened the buckles as Charlie reaches into of the Colonel’s bureau; medals, ribbons, a ceremonial da trove of military honors in dusty disarray. SLADE (contd) The epaulets with the silver oak leaf! Charlie locates the Lt. Colonel insignia, lifts the garme out of the closet, Slade zips it open, affixes the should boards, expertly folds the dress uniform into the Val-Pak it shut. SLADE (contd) We're all set.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: See if the cab is here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Freak Show Central.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: New York City.
Charlie blinks. SLADE (contd) That’s located in New York State, son.

dialogues.speaker: _ CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rossi didn’t say anything about going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: She forgot. Charlie measures hin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well -- maybe we should wait and call her. She gave me her number --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: They just hit the road. Between piss calls for those kids and that Hupmobile he drives, by the time they get to Albany it/’1l be opening day at Saratoga.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can’t go to New York.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s too much responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t. I had a lot of seventeen year olds in my first platoon. Slade reaches into his rear trouser pocket. SLADE (contd) Tickets -- (right trouser pocket) Money -- (inside suit coat pocket) Speech. He smiles devilishly at Charlie. ~ SLADE (contd) An old Washington joke. (runs his tongue over his teeth) From my days with Lyndon. The HONK of a horn.
SLADE (contd) I knew I could count on Transportation. Are you ready? Charlie, fighting for time, remains silent. SLADE (contd) Hello! This is not Panmunjom, a simple ‘yes’ will do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Umm --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s what I like to hear! Get my bag. Slade crouches and Tommy, the cat, leaps into his arms. SLADE (contd) (nuzzling the cat) When in doubt, Tomster, fuck. The horn HONKS again, he dumps Tommy, reaches for Charlie and they head out. SLADE (contd) Don't rush. They always hold the plane for field grade officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up to the curb, its door flies open and a ca probes the air as curbside, a SKYCAP hustles to greet the arriving passengers. Charlie, emerging from the other doo hurries around to the trunk for the bag as Slade hands th Skycap the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: SKYCAP
dialogues.text: Yes sir, two for the shuttle to New York --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: We’re not shuttling anywhere, we’re riding First Class! The Skycap checks the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: SKYCAP
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mr. Simms and Colonel Slade. " First Class. As the Skycap takes the bag, Charlie turns to Slade.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You bought a ticket for me? What made you think I’d go to New York?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Are you some chicken-shit who sticks to the job description? The Skycap staples a baggage check to the tickets. Charli reaches for them but Slade bashes his hand away, takes th himself. Slade extends a ten-spot to the Skycap who happi accepts it. SLADE (contd) (to the Skycap) As you were, Sarge -- The Skycap salutes as Slade strides off holding his arm o Charlie running to catch up to it. SLADE (contd) Are you blind?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Of course not --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Then what are you taking my goddamn arm for, I take your arn.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t be sorry, how would you know? You’ve been watching MTV all your life.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel, I can’t go to New York, hey look, I’m --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t ‘hey, look’ me! This is New York we’re talking about. This is an opportunity, squirt. Now listen up. There are two kinds of people in this world. Working Stiffs who stick to the lesson plan, and Wild Talents who go for the brass ring. Which are you going to be? Before Charlie can answer -- SLADE (contd) . Never mind, I‘’1l take care of you. Slade takes Charlie by the arm, squeezes his bicep, Charl grimaces.

SLADE (contd) Two oysters wrapped in rags. (to Charlie) Half step ahead. Guide on, soldier. Charlie leads the way, the Colonel striding on, swinging cane as he goes, his head tilted at a sharp angle that se slash through the outside world. SLADE (contd) And stay on the right side, there are women on the left. They switch sides, a salacious smile on the Colonel’s lip aims his nose at every female passerby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncrowded plane, Slade’s seat is on the aisle, he tune radar to the approach of a shapely Flight Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Can I get you gentlemen anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Triple Jack Daniels, water back. Charlie winces, makes a narrow gesture to the Flight Atte with his thumb and forefinger, "water it." She nods conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) And for you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: It’s First Class, Peewee, it comes with the fare.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What are you, a Temperance Union?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want anything --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Flight Attendant) To complete the order, Daphne, give Andy Hardy here a Diet Slice, water back. The Flight Attendant moves off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did you know her name?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: She’s wearing Floris. That’s English. But her voice is pure California chickie. California chickie bucking for English lady. So I call her Daphne. (pokes an elbow) Big things may happen to that little thing of yours.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Look, Colonel, 1/11 get you to New York but then I’m going to have to turn right around and come back.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Of course you will. The Flight Attendant returns with Slade’s drink, hurries He takes a sip, makes a face. SLADE (contd) Who’s mixing the drinks here, The Flintstones? : He swallows a big gulp anyway. SLADE (contd) Try that again, you’re getting out at Hartford.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The flight is non-stop.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You'll get out at Hartford anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wish I could. I don’t belong on this plane. I don’t belong in New York.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about ‘pelonging,’ sonny, there’s only one club to belong to. That’s your own. Make your own rules, be your own Board of Governors. Pay your own dues. . Slade drains his drink, reaches into his vest pocket for flask, splashes more dark liquid over the watery rocks, f it to the edge. Charlie watches in horror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why are we going to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade sighs. 33.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: All information will be given on a need-to-know basis. (craning his head) Where’s Daphne? Let’s get her down ere.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s way in the back.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The tail’s in the tail. He sniffs again. SLADE (contd) I can still smell her. Women. Who made them? God was a fucking genius. What a mind the guy must’ve had. The hair -- they say the hair is everything. Have you ever buried your nose in a mountain of curls and just wanted to go to sleep forever? And lips that when they touch yours are that first swallow of wine after you’ve just crossed the desert? Slade is deep into a reverie. SLADE (contd) Tits. Big ones, little ones, bury your face in them and nipples that stare at you like secret searchlights. Legs, I don’t care if they’re Greek columns or second-hand Steinways, between them is a passport to heaven. Don’t think I can’t see women because I can’t see women. I’m a Female Traffic Controller, Charlie, I can bring them in. With my nose, with my ears. What is it about them? "What do they want?" Who cares what they want. They’re wonderful. Yes, Mr. Simms, there are only two syllables in this whole wide world worth hearing -- Pussy! Charlie, struck dumb by Slade’s passion, remains silent. SLADE (contd) Are you listening to me? I’m giving you pearls here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I guess you really like women.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Above all things. Slade refills his drink, there is no ice left, so he down straight. A helpless Charlie can only watch. SLADE (contd) -- A very, very distant second isa Ferrari. (a moment) This air jockey’s not bad. 450 knots, about 10,000 feet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charles, this is just the start of your education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls into the line of unloading limos, unloading the main entrance redolent with the hustle and bustle of well-coiffed women and sharp men, expensive luggage waiti shiny-brass hydrants to be sent upstairs, a burly Doorman huge epaulets and rows of gold buttons, blowing the hell a silver whistle. Charlie is seated in the taxi next to the Colonel. Peerin the window at the swanky sights, Charlie seems overcome. Doorman swings their door open.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Slade) Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (Nirvana) ; The Waldorf-Astoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade and Charlie follow JAIME, their bellman, up the ste and into the giant lobby, floor-to-ceiling murals, chambe . music issuing from public rooms.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ...It’s the last of the great lobbies. Relax in an easy chair, smoke a Havana. Watch the women go by and when you’ve found the right one, an urn of sand to douse your cigar. Jaime waits patiently until Charlie and Slade catch up.

SLADE (contd) ...Last time I was here was with two of Madame Nhu’s generals. Couldn’t shoot an azimuth, but could they find the coordinates for a hooker? Talk about ass-men. Those little vietnamese bandits were not lacking for testosterone. No sir! They arrive at the desk. SLADE (contd) Yes sir, my kind of inn.

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: (to Clerk) Colonel Slade and Mr. Simms.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: We have your reservation right here, Colonel --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (intimately) Mr. Gilbert around -- or is he back on days? The Clerk is momentarily puzzled. SLADE (contd) (impatient) You know, the honcho -- what have they done, booted him upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Oh yes...Mr. Gilbert. He’s not been with us for a number of years. Slade sniffs, Charlie remains all bewildered by the surroundings. CLERK (contd) ...We’ve got a nice junior executive for you, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Delete the ‘junior.’

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: very good, sir. The Clerk gives a different set of keys to Jaime.

dialogues.speaker: " SAIME
dialogues.text: Right this way, gentlemen. 2203. Beautiful corner suite. Slade seems appeased, he makes an abrupt right turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36. JAIME (contd) (to Slade) No sir, this way.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The elevators are over here!

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Colonel, the doors were changed to the other side of the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: I think about five years ago. Slade takes a deep intake of breath.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: They’re putting too much Lysol in the heads. (to Charlie) Follow him. Charlie follows Jaime, Slade on Charlie’s arm as they app the elevators. SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) ...First time I came here was with the G-2 from Brussels. He had a Ferrari. I had to hold the door every day for the fucker, never even offered me a ride...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade and Charlie are side-by-side behind Jaime who presi over the luggage. Behind them in a corner of the elevator elderly Racquet Club-type in a Trilby hat.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Jaime) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: Jaime.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, Hyman, should I want some of -- an indefinable gesture) ...this...I call for you? Or, who's working the street, the doorman?

dialogues.speaker: . JAIME
dialogues.text: Sir -- sir, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37. Jaime at a loss, turns to Charlie for help.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Whose department is it, Hyman? Jaime gestures helplessly to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Slade, gently) Colonel, I think he’s trying to tell you he doesn’t really know ~~

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hey! Don’t translate for me! I know how to talk to a man in uniform! The sudden tension in the elevator subsides as Slade peer his shoulder at the man in the corner, smiles, turns back Jaime, knowingly. SLADE (contd) I’m with you, Hyman. Classified. Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaine waits discreetly as Slade riffles through a sheaf o ills.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Spread the word -- Slade hands Jaime a generous tip. SLADE (contd) And the intelligence will be forthcoming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: on the escort scene!

dialogues.speaker: JAIME
dialogues.text: Uhh -- yes, sir. And welcome to the Waldorf. Jaime goes. SLADE . Puerto Ricans always made the best infantrymen. Slade taps his way around the room, orienting himself to area. He comes to a dead end against a wall, turns and st into the mini-bar. He discerns the shape of it with his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie opens nearby. 38. SLADE (contd) Give me an inventory. the mini-bar as Slade locates the telephone SLADE (contd) (phone) Get me ‘21’. Charlie squats by the mini-bar, searching through the con SLADE (contd) (phone) Is Sheldon or Mac there? While Slade waits, Charlie reports to him on the contents mini-bar.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Early Times, Jim Beam. Lots of little bottles... Slade makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Quartermaster’s on the take again. (into phone) ...This is Colonel Frank Slade, one of your old regulars. Used to come in with General Garbisch... (smiles) Well, that’s probably because he’s at Arlington, six feet under. Now listen up, I want a table for two, and I’m talking the fireplace up front. 8:15. He taps the phone cradle, disconnecting his phone call. Slade hangs w| SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) Clear them little bottles out. Call Hyman when I get off, tell him I want it wall-to-wall with John Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You mean Jack Daniels?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: He may be Jack to you but when you know him as well as I do -- . (into phone) Colonel Slade...get me a limo for 8 o’clock. p, takes a swig from his flask, a deep, satisfied intake of breath through his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 39. SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) What are you drinking? Charlie, to avoid an answer, keeps rearranging the conten the mini-bar. Impatient, Slade holds out his flask to Cha

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No thanks, I don’t use it.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s useful about it?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno. Hey look, Colonel, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have to get back to school, I got some reai important stuff I got to take care of.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Very well. But I never let my aides leave on an empty stomach. You’1ll dine with me, and then my driver will transport you to the airport for the Boston shuttle departing at 2200 hours. Unpack my bag, I’m going to christen the latrine. Slade gets up, breaks into a little two-step as he heads bathroon. SLADE (contd) ...Feels like morning of the Notre Dame game. (sings) ‘Sons of Mars and Thunder Rip that line asunder Carry on to victory -- ’ He shuts the bathroom door. Charlie opens Slade’s bag, st to unpack for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade looks dazzling in an expensive suit. Charlie, still his rumpled sweater, slumped in the rear seat next to Sla seems a thousand miles away, Slade pushes a button, his w rolls down, Slade turning his head this way and that.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: New York, New York -- smells good. (a moment) What have we got, a red light? Nothing like a red light on Park Avenue. All those tits hurrying to cross the street -- Paradise! What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: With me?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The car feels heavy, you know why? Because you’ve got the fucking weight of the world on your shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I have a little problem at school -~

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No big deal. Where’re we going again? Twenty-what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So it’s no big deal? Then why is it ‘real important stuff’?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why is what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The ‘little problem’. Been banging the headmaster’s daughter? Charlie, giving in to the interrogation, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m in a little trouble --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What kind of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I saw some guys doing something -~

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Doing what? ~ Charlie falls silent. SLADE (contd) To tell or not to tell -- or it’s your ass.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I didn’t run S-2 for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Intelligence! Give me the details. Charlie hesitates under Slade’s glare.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you see there’s this guy, Harry, he’s this real rich kid and he kind of runs things, and --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Who else -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This other guy, George. He didn’t do anything. But he and I saw Harry and his guys do something.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: George a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s not my friend but he’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You trust him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Is he on scholarship, too?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. Why? Slade leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What's your name, driver?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Manny, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Manny, do you know Hyman?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Hyman?  42.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hyman, the baggage-smasher at the Waldorf.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Slade) I think his name is Jaime.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s him. Jaime.

dialogues.speaker: . MANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, Jaime Esperanza-Chavez?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I dian’t ask for his lineage, I asked whether you knew hin.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I do.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Jaime any good at getting escorts?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What would you know?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: About you-know-what! Manny, in troubled bewilderment, squints. SLADE (contd) Well -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe I could manage something.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You mean for a fee?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Let me think about this, sir --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m talking top-of-the-line. Slade turns to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLADE (contd) Okay, we got Harry, we got George. And we got trouble. They’re rich, you’re poor. (MORE)
SLADE (contd) But you want to get rich. You want to graduate from Baird and become a rich bigshot. Like them, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not that way at all -- Manny pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Here we are, ‘21’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "21" Doorman opens Slade’s door, Slade emerges follow Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Lighten up. When we get into dinner, I’11 tell you what to do. Meanwhile, let go of it, for Christ’s sake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAITRE D’ leads Slade and Charlie into the dining roo

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Where are you taking us? MAITRE D’ We have a nice table for you in our new East Room. Slade, his hand on Charlie’s arn, stops. The Maitre da’, unaware, continues on. SLADE . (to Charlie) -- By the fireplace. Charlie heads for the fireplace, there is a vacant table Slade feels the chairs, takes a seat as if he owned the p SLADE (contd) This’1l do. The Maitre d’ reappears. MAITRE D’ * This table is reserved, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I appreciate your holding it for us. Menus, please, and a double Jack Daniels on the rocks.

A Cloakroom Attendant hands the resigned Maitre d’ an all-purpose blazer. MAITRE D’ (to Charlie) Perhaps you'll be more comfortable in this, sir. He helps Charlie on with the jacket, the sleeves a bit lo shoulders too tight.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You look great. The Maitre d’ gives Slade and Charlie menus, tenderly fol the collar on Charlie’s blazer, and heads back to the fro SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) ‘21,’ a table by the fireplace, and you got a brand new jacket -- Kid, we're cooking. Now read me the Bill of Fare. Charlie opens the menu as Slade drinks in the atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘21’ Burger with fries -- twenty-four dollars --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Where’s the booze, it’s flowing like mud around here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Twenty-four-dollar hamburger. What’s the story?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What story? CHARLIE . Are you a rich miser or something?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m just your average blind man.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, average blind man. How are you going to pay for all of this? SLADE . Crisp, clean dollars -- American. I saved up my disability checks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: For the twenty-four-dollar burger or the chicken and mashed at twenty-nine? And how much did you save? First Class on the plane, the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: It’s all part of a plan, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, could you let me in on it?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why do you give a shit? You’re taking the last shuttle out of La Guardia. Slade suddenly jerks his wrist to his eyes as if he were checking a watch. SLADE (contd) Oops, you got fifteen minutes. I don’t think you can make it. Unless ‘21’ keeps a complimentary helicopter on the roof. Slade studies his "watch" again. SLADE (contd) Nope, you’re stuck here until tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, you said the last shuttle was 2200 hours. That’s 10 ofclock, right?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Last I heard.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s only 8:30. Slade’s drink arrives, he takes a swallow.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I lied. It leaves at 9.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It leaves at 9?!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes, it does. A moment, Slade sensing Charlie’s anger. SLADE (contd) The truth is, Charlie, I need a guide dog to help me execute my plan.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What plan? Slade smiles. .

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You have a right to know. It’s not really a plan, Charlie. More like a tour. A little tour of pleasures. Stay in a first-class hotel, eat an agreeable meal, drink a nice glass of wine, see my big brother -- there’s nothing like family, you know -- and then make love to a terrific woman. After that --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m going to lie down on my beautiful bed at the Waldorf and blow my brains out. The Waiter appears.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Can I tell you our specials?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: By all means. Charlie is staring at Slade.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Tonight we have Charred Venison with Buckwheat Spaetzle and Green Peppercorns. Grilled Veal Paillarde with Tomato Tapenade and Roasted Eggplant -- Slade’s head is pleasantly tilted at the Waiter, but Char riveted on Slade, trying to ascertain what he said. WAITER (contd) And if you would like our Crepes Souffle for dessert, it would be a good idea to order it now.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes on the Souffle, give us half a minute on the rest.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That means, Alphonse, don’t go too far.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (indicating next table) I/11 just pour some wine over here, sir. The Waiter moves away, Slade turns to Charlie conspirator

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m leaning towards the Spaetzle. Slade falls pleasantly silent, gazes around the room in h blind way, Charlie can’t take his eyes off him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel Slade?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you say you were going to blow your brains out?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Did I say that? The Waiter returns from the adjacent table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Have you decided, sir? i SLADE | (to Charlie) | Going for the burger? | (to the Waiter) | Give him the ‘21’ Hamburger medium rare, and I’1l take the Chicken Hash i on a Waffle. Also, save us some bread pudding.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes sir, thank you. Charlie doesn’t know which way to turn. He starts to say thing, ends up saying another.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Chicken Hash on a Waffle?’

dialogues.speaker: SLADE -
dialogues.text: Twenty-four dollars. Delicious. And only the insiders know about the bread pudding. Big Ed always put away three helpings. ! Slade reaches across the table, locates the bread tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 48. SLADE (contd) Try one of these rolls. I used to dream of these rolls when I was at Fort Huachuca. The bread’s no good west of the Colorado. The water’s too alkaline.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel Slade, did I hear you right? You said you were going to kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No, I said I was going to blow my brains out. Eat this roll, Charlie, I buttered it for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want a roll.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, have a radish. Where were we? Oh yes, the agenda. We're also going to need to buy you some clothes. Is Rogers Peet still around? They cut a helluva mess jacket. Slade grabs a passing Waiter. SLADE (contd) Get me a double Jack Daniels on the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes sir, right away. Charlie makes a gesture to the Waiter with his thumb and forefinger, a "weak drink," the Waiter nods, hurries away

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Please don’t do that. Directly behind Slade, the Maitre d’ seats an elegant, yo couple. Slade drinks in the beautiful woman’s scent, intoxicated by her presence, as a very sober Charlie trac every move. SLADE (contd) What a marvelous place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie stands by as Slade moves tentatively around the r again, re-orienting himself with his cane, tapping object moving on. He slaps a couch, reaches underneath the pillo feels a handle.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Your billet’s here. In the morning, the area will be returned to sitting room mode no later than 0700 hours. Charlie salutes, Slade flinches. An ominous silence. SLADE (contd) What was that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Next time, snap it out, thumb to palm, index through little digit aligned smartly, sharp to the hairline and own! Slade lets Charlie stew through another anxious silence. SLADE (contd) Too many men far better than you have executed that courtesy and if you know what’s good for you, don’t try it again... Charlie holds himself very still. SLADE (contd) This bat’s got sharper radar than the Nautilus. Don’t fuck with me, Charlie. Slade lifts his cane, taps his way into his bedroon. SLADE (contd) See that you get a good night’s sleep. Slade closes his door, Charlie stares at it for a moment. sits down on the couch, he glances around the fancy hotel sitting room; damask drapes, directoire chairs, a fake Fr antique desk. An air of bewilderment in Charlie gives way resignation. He stands up, removes the cushions from the and pulls out the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie awakens with a start. A room service cart rests a the wall. Charlie finds Slade standing on a footstool in of a three-paneled mirror. A female tailor, SOFIA, 24, is fitting him with a pair of trousers. Slade hears the rust Charlie’s covers as he arises.

dialogues.speaker: ___ SLADE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: ___ CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofia smiles pulls on his carefully. 50.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: This is Sofia, Charlie. Descended from a long line of Florentine pants makers, she is a magician with a needle. Sofia’s working me up a little gabardine number and I’ve already picked you out a blazer and flannels. Juice, coffee and assorted goodies on the trolley. Why don’t you get up and get yourself together. brightly at Charlie. He gets up, in his underwear, pants, pours some coffee in a cup, surveys Slade

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How’re you feeling today, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Super! You know Sofia here’s working Thanksgiving because she is putting herself through college. I told her my friend, Charlie, here was also headed for college. The word "college" jolts Charlie wide awake, he crosses t Slade’s bedroom. SLADE (contd) Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To make a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with this phone?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You're not disturbing me. Make your call.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’d like to be private...

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Stay out of my room, this is as private as you’re going to get. Charlie reluctantly sits down at the desk, dials the oper

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (phone) Vermont information, please. At the mirror, Sofia is pinning Slade’s new trousers. He smiles at her, she smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: How I’d love to fit you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (phone) I don’t know exactly, it’s the Sugarbush Lodge.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Sugar -- (smiles) Bush. Charlie dials a number as Sofia continues to work on Slad

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (phone) George Willis, please.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi George, it’s Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, how’re you doing, why didn’t you call last night?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t get a chance until --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You okay? You sound funny.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Next year, you’ve got to come up with us. White powder on a base of snow bunnies. Charlie doesn’t answer. GEORGE (V.0.) (contd) Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m here. You asked me to call you about the moves -~

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For now, the move is no move. Status quo. Everything’s the way we left it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How did we leave it? After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: See no evil, hear no evil, you know what I mean, Chas?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. See no evil, hear no evil.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ease out, everything’s going to be all right. You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Walk like you talk. The phone clicks off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Bye. Charlie stares at the phone. Sofia is busy measuring Slad leg. Slade’s head tilts towards Charlie. .

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s George’s last name?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Willis.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: George Willis. That makes his father George Willis, Senior. Charlie, how do you think Big George is going to feel about Little George ‘seeing no evil’ and ‘hearing no evil’?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No one is telling their parents. We're keeping it between us.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh, you think George isn’t going to talk to his father about this? Damn ~ decent of him. What does George’s father do?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Well, I’11 tell you. When George Willis, Sr. is not busy as a million-dollar man for Aetna Casualty or is it New England distributor for the Chrysler Corporation -- he concerns himself with George Willis, Jr. That’s what he does.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: George isn’t going to talk to his father.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Of course not. (to Sofia) Oops --

dialogues.speaker: SOFIA
dialogues.text: *Scusi, Colonello.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Prego, I love it when you hurt me. (whispers, to Charlie) Is she -- ? Slade makes a pumping motion with his fist towards Sofia.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ummm -- uhh --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, got it. Where was I? _Oh yeah, Big George didn’t get to be President of Massachusetts Gear and Electric for nothing. He’ll wind Little George up and Little George will sing like a canary. Good-bye Harry, hello Ivy League and if you’re hip, Kid, you’1l hop to, too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Listen up, it don’t take no National Merit Scholarship to figure this one out. You had a little life, Charlie. So you came to Baird to put yourself ~ in the market for a big one. If you want to stay in the running, you’re going to have to tell them what they want to know.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: If you don’t sing, Charlie, you’ll end up Shelving biscuits ina convenience store in the Oregon ‘burbs. (to Sofia) That’s enough, Compari, now run something up for Charlie here pronto, we've got a date for Thanksgiving. A date? ° ve

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: My brother’s place, W.R. Slade, White Plains, New York. The Plains, of course, are neither white nor plains, nevertheless located in fashionable Westchester County.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can’t go to your brother’s place. I should be getting back to school.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: C’mon, Charlie, you’ve got to have Thanksgiving Dinner somewhere. Eats ‘n treats. And I could use the company. This registers on Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Does he know I’m coming?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know I’m coming. But wait till you see the look on his face when I walk through the door. Slade beams. SLADE (contd) He adores me. Slade steps off the footstool, extends an open palm, Char fits Slade’s cane into it. Slade motions Charlie on to th footstool. SLADE (contd) There are two kinds of people in this ~ world, Charlie. Those who stand up and face the music. And those who run for cover. He taps his way towards his bedroom. SLADE (contd) Cover is better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manny driving, Slade and Charlie seated in the back, they great in their new clothes. Slade picks up the intercom phone.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Any progress on the ‘action’? What ‘action’?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What ‘action’ do you think I’m talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, that ‘action’. Yes sir, yes sir, the action is progressing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) What are you looking at? Charlie is startled by Slade’s "antennae".

dialogues.speaker: / CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘ Your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You like these shoes?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You know how much these shoes cost?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Eleven hundred dollars. Lobb’s of London. Six months.
