A shoe architect measures your feet, carves the last out of solid maple, then the ‘clicker’, he’s the hide man, cuts eight pieces of leather exactly to specifications, a ‘closer’ sews them, . sixteen stitches to the inch, the ‘maker’ cuts heel and sole, and finally the ‘polisher’, he gives them that dull, expensive look. Eleven hundred dollars, Charlie, and worth every penny of it. Nineteen years, } these babies.
Charlie, staring at the shoes, whistles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They still seem brand new.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m leaving them to you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re about my size. Next week when I’m secured, drop by the house and pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, ‘secured’?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Dead. Tell Karen I said they were yours.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t like it when you kid around like this, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t be more serious.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then I’m going to have to go back to school.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good idea. Manny honks, swerves past some pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Suicide, Colonel Slade, is a crime.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s your opinion and, of course, the conventional wisdom. Look at the Eskimos, you know the squaws, check right out when they get old.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who says?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Squaws chew leather. Chew the skins ‘til they’re soft enough to sew them into clothing with bones they’ve whittled down. When those ladies’ teeth are too far gone to soften leather, they take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Take a walk?’

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Out of the igloo. Into the tundra. Goom-bye.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I studied Eskimos in Anthropology. That’s bullshit. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. But, Charlie, what should the old bags do when they can’t pull their weight? No one’s too eager to tear a herring with them anymore. Slade is smiling slyly. He crosses and uncrosses his shoe SLADE (contd) I always liked a good pair of shoes. When you’re making love to a beautiful woman, who’s looking at you but your shoes? Charlie turns away, stares out the window moodily.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ..-There’s a Ferrari dealer. Slade picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Manny) Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salesman, FRED BISCO, looks up from his desk, through t showroom window he sees Manny scurry around the limousine the door for Slade. Charlie leads Slade across the sidewa the showroom, but the door is locked. Fred gets up, goes door, unlocks it, holds it ajar.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We’re closed.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: It’s Thanksgiving. I was just catching up on my paperwork while the wife took the kids to the parade.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Interested in selling a car or not?
Fred looks at Manny standing at attention beside his shin limo, observes the neat cut of Slade’s suit and that of h companion’s, Charlie. .

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Come in. He opens the door wide, and Charlie leads Slade inside, h getting practiced "orienting" him. Slade stops in front o gleaming, red Ferrari, hooks his cane over his elbow and the shape of the car with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Testarossa...Mondial?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Testarossa.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Did they get the horses up to 350?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) The D.O.T. wouldn’t let them bring it in, in '85. Slade opens the door of the Ferrari, closes it, opens it salutes some unseen figure, closes it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (a whisper, to Charlie) Could you watch the cane?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Fred) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Fred.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Fred what?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Fred Bisco.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Fred, never mind the cane, you’re looking at a live one here. Fred watches in horror as Slade’s cane now comes close to glimmering finish of the Testarossa, he starts to reach o Slade but Charlie politely restrains Fred’s arm. Slade mo another car, runs his hands over it gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 SLADE (contd)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘tb’ or ‘ts’? Feels like a ‘ts’.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: On the money, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) On the money is right. Slade caresses this car, touches the shape of the open ro feels the leather-embossed wheel through the window, he i of tender love for this machine. ~ SLADE (contd) G-2 needed a big Testarossa for his little dick. I prefer the open air, the flowing coed hair, of the ‘ts’. (to Fred) Where are these located now, one hundred and a quarter?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: For you sir, a hundred thirteen eight.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Is that list?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Then why is it for me? Fred can’t answer. SLADE (contd) It’s your list, not mine. Shame on you, Freddie Bisco. Slade reaches for Charlie’s arm, they turn to walk out. SLADE (contd) (to Fred) I/1l compare prices with your colleagues in Jersey and Connecticut and who knows -- we could be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up to an upscale house in a development, fieldstone ground floors with white frame second stories. hurries around to the rear door, holds it open, helps Sla

Charlie steps out behind Slade, takes his arm, leads him the house. Manny settles back into the limousine as Charl rings the bell. Curtains part at a window. At the window is RANDY, early Slade’s nephew, he looks out with pained surprise, the cu gyose. Randy opens the door, he surveys Slade, Charlie pr im up.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Randy.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Randy.’ You new? Randy looks from Charlie to Slade and back again.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: I’m your nephew.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Randy. Here we are. Your sister’s been hoarding me long enough. Time to spread the riches around. Randy calls into the house:

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Dad -- But before Randy gets a response, GAIL, 27, his attractiv appears.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Uncle Frank!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Gail) Gloria --

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Gail --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Of course. Say hello to the potluck * party from New York. Your Uncle Frank and this is Charlie Simms, star halfback on The Baird School football team. They not only beat Exeter and Groton, Aquinas High School, too. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 61. SLADE (contd) (to Randy) Where’s your miserable father, no, let’s surprise him. See if we can give that fat heart of his an attack. (calling out) Willie! INT. W.R. SLADES’S HOUSE - DAY 45 In the living room, two men are watching the NFL game on television, W.R., mid-50’s, a messy overweight sort in a 3-piece suit, with him his younger son, GARRY, 25. W.R. Do you hear what I hear?

dialogues.speaker: GARRY
dialogues.text: I hear it. W.R. heads for the front door, GRETCHEN, W.R.’s wife emer from the kitchen, Garry gets up and joins them, the famil now gathered at the front door in stricken wonderment. W.R. (a deathly whisper) Hello, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Willie, there you are! Home for Thanksgiving for a change. Charlie, meet W.R. Slade, the original bulging briefcase man. Went from Lading Clerk on the Lackawanna Railroad to bankruptcy referee in 12 easy jumps. God breaks ’em and Willie busts ‘em. Gretch! I smell those prunes! Are we talking Turkey Marbella?! He opens his arms in the direction of the kitchen, falls Gretchen, nuzzles her. SLADE (contd) Give us a whiff, you know I’ve always had a sneaker for you. In the confusion W.R., beet-red, turns to Charlie. W.R. Who are you? .

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m just here at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with -- is it your brother? Slade, who has had Gretchen backed against the wall, rele her with mock romantic reluctance.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Garry, where’s my drink, it’s flowing like mud around here? He takes a swallow from his flask. W.R. (to Charlie) Yes, he’s my brother. Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m kind of his companion for a few days -- umm -- to tell you the truth, the Colonel is not well. W.R. ‘Not well?!’

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He seems kind of lonely. W.R. Why don’t you take him to your family’s for dinner? Slade starts poking his way towards the living room, the parting at the wave of his cane.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to W.R.) I meant to pick up some vino on the way up, but I blew it. I’1l send you the Rothschild again for Christmas -- but let’s see how Thanksgiving goes. Gretchen opens the dining room doors.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: ‘Dinner is served’. Randy presses a drink in Slade’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Here you are, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Still with Domino Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Jack Frost. Why do you always get it - wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Because it’s not important to me to get it right. What are you now?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Vice-President for Marketing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Slade sniffs Slade’s cane 63.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Sugar’s shit. I told General Abrams to install honey in the commissaries. If the K-50’s didn’t blow your brains out, the sugar would. Randy, may I tell you your bosses killed more men than the Gooks? (sniffs) The olives are heating up, you knew I was coming didn’t you, Gretch? (to Charlie) She stuffs the bird with olives and prunes, Stays up all night to cook it for me.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Could we sit down? Gail.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Mitsouki. (sniffs her again, to Randy) Rhymes with nookie. Watch out. When the wife gets restless, the wife gets racy. W.R. Let’s eat!

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (to Slade) Where do you want to sit, Frank, or are you going to arrange yourself at the head again?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh, any old card table will do. hits the head of the table. SLADE (contd) This is fine. He sits himself down. SLADE (contd) Charlie! Next to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty dishes, half-filled coffee cups, everybody in a stu glaze as Slade holds forth.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ..-So what am I going to do, I’ve got this Asian flower on the one hand, and this Navy nurse-on the other, we’re three across the bed, not a stitch of clothes on and it comes to me. Let East meet West and we’1l build The Golden Bridge. Gail looks as if she were about to throw up. SLADE (contd) I felt like I’d just joined the Corps of Engineers. Slade howls, his head darts about looking for approval, t is none forthcoming. ‘The only affect is Charlie dying of embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Did you always enjoy shocking people, Uncle Frank?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: (cautioning) Honey --

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Dad, remember the day you persuaded Frank to go to the kennel?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Randy) What about it?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (chuckling) He almost put the seeing eye dog business out of business. W.R. Randy, cool it. He glances at Slade. W.R. (contd) (to Randy) Water over the dam, son.

dialogues.speaker: GARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, over and done with.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Indeed it is, Garry. And so is dinner. What time is it, we’ve got to be getting back?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Ever given any thought to a Braille watch, Frank? Stevie Wonder wears one er do you rank on him, too?

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Honey, please --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s all right, Gloria, I enjoy Randy's observations. I’ve always found him a very amusing guy.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: My wife’s name is Gail.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Gail -- strikes me as a very beautiful young woman but there’s a little tension in her voice. That can mean one of two things -- Gail is either nervous or unsatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: What’s your point, Uncle Frank?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You ought to go down on her. W.R. Jee-zus.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Randy) You’ve gotten so wrapped up with the sugar business, you’ve forgotten the taste of honey.

dialogues.speaker: GAIL
dialogues.text: Frank, for god’s sakes!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Gail) Grace, I’ve always been crazy about you.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (to Slade) Why don’t you get out of here? Take that limousine down to the Bowery. Get with the other lushes where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute -- RANDY . What for, Chuckie, you think he’s special because he’s blind?  66.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: My friend’s name is Charles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Randy) Yes, he’s special and he’s blind.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Another sucker who thinks this shitheel is a war hero. W.R. Randy, that’s enough --

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) He blew himself up.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Stop it, Randy.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Our Colonel here had this grenade- juggling act at Fort Bragg --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Fort Benning.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: He was teaching hand-to-hand combat to Second Lieutenants at the Infantry School --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Look at me, Randy, when you’re talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: His partner in the act was some Captain --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Major Vincent Squires.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Whoever he was, before going on, they’d have themselves a lo-cal breakfast. Screwdriver for Frank, Bloody Mary for his partner. SLADE . vinnie drank Sea Breezes.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: The Judge-Advocate at Benning says Colonel Slade had four to his partner’s one. (MORE)

RANDY (contd) He was really flying at class, he got excited and started pulling the pins. One grenade got away from him. The pin was in, he claims. In or out, what’s the difference, what kind of showboating lunatic juggles grenades?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Vinnie came out okay --

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: And all Frank lost was his eyesight. (to Charlie) Well, he was an asshole before. Now all he is, is a blind asshole. But nothing could make me happier. Some people don’t deserve to see. You get the picture, Chuckie? Suddenly Slade is up, jams Randy against the wall, he wra arm terrifyingly around Randy’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: His name is Charles. You can say that, can’t you? ‘Charles’. Randy is choking, Gail and Gretchen screaming, W.R. and G tear at Slade but he is too powerful for them. SLADE (contd) You know what this is, Randy? It’s a chokehold, they teach it to you at Ranger School. A little pressure and I bust your windpipe. Now -- ‘Charles’. After me -- ‘Charles’. Randy, against the wall, has gone blue. Suddenly, between two combatants, Charlie shoves his way through. Slade sen hin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: c'mon, Colonel, c’mon =~ Unconsciously, Slade eases up. Gretchen and Gail are froz the kitchen door, Garry blinks emptily and W.R. doesn’t k which way to turn. Slade removes a pristine napkin which tucked under his chin for dinner, dots both corners of hi mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Gretchen, you outdid yourself. He releases the napkin, it drops on the floor in_a damask crumple, Slade reaches out for Charlie, and Charlie is th an instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 48 68. SLADE (contd) (to Gretchen) If you twist my arm hard enough, and we're talking Turkey Marbella next year, who knows...? A terrible SILENCE. Slade finds a wine glass on the table glass, he starts to raise it to his lips. W.R. Frank? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good-bye. Slade extends his hand, W.R. looks at it, shakes it. SLADE (contd) Willie, I’m no fucking good and I never have been. Slade raises his wine in a toast. SLADE (contd) Here’s looking at you. He taps the glass against his glass eye. PING! He polishe the wine. Charlie leads Slade out now, leaving W.R. and h bewildered family behind. EXT. W.R.’S HOUSE - WHITE PLAINS - NIGHT 47 Slade comes down the path towards the limo with Charlie. jumps out, opens the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Nueva York, compadre. Vamos. Slade and Charlie get in, Manny closes the door, climbs b the wheel and drives them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, toothbrush in hand, wanders into Slade’s bedroom Slade, his face wreathed in a lascivious smile, is proppe his pillows listening to the television where two big-bre women cavort topless on a water bed. Slade wears a patch, beside him on a bedside table, a glass eye rests in a liq solution. Charlie notices it, the iris, colored a deep bl stares up intensely at him.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-A little taste of Cindy and Mindy, the most delightful duet in town. They will turn those dreams into a reality. Our operators are waiting by the phones --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What are they doing now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel, you know what they’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m blind, you little prick! What’s happening?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s a sleaze show --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Sleaze?!’ ‘Sleaze?!’ Cindy and Mindy are the Meryl Streep of the New Age.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re an employee, Simms. Keep your opinions to yourself. Slade sips from his flask, shakes a pill out of a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing, taking pills with liquor?! Charlie snatches the bottle of pills away from Slade, tri read the label. CHARLIE (contd) squinting) What are these?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: My German downers. Give ‘em back here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel Slade --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: GIVE ‘EM BACK! Charlie hands him the pills. SLADE (contd) Pull duty with NATO, you eat and drink like a king, then they send you to a spa to sweat it out. He washes the pill down with whiskey, caps the bottle lov

SLADE (contd) Baden-Baden. Every night they award you one of these little greenies and you sleep like a gnome in the Black Forest. He shakes the bottle of pills, enjoying the SOUND. __SLADE (contd) They’re still green, aren’t they? Charlie gets up and heads for his room. SLADE (contd) Hey, runt! Charlie turns around. SLADE (contd) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Back to bed. Slade smiles enigmatically, Charlie stares anxiously at h Slade’s eye is blinking closed peacefully. Charlie moves the sitting room now, tries to fix up his mussed-up bed, can’t get comfortable. He lies there in the darkness. A THUD. Charlie jumps up, runs into Slade’s room, Slade h fallen out of bed, is lying face-down beside it. On the n table the bottle of German sleeping pills, now empty, lie its side.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel! Colonel! He shakes him desperately. CHARLIE (contd) For God’s sake, wake up! Slade lies still, his jaw slack, Charlie lunges for the telephone but keeps Slade in view, Slade’s one eye opens Charlie blinks into the shining, sea-blue iris. Suddenly Slade’s face lights up, breaks into a smile, he starts la feels under the skirt of the bedside table, pulls out a l vase into which he has poured the pills, now spills them in the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE -
dialogues.text: You’re easy -- Charlie hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s not funny.  49

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie, my boy, you got no sense of humor. Slade leans back in bed, presses a button on the TV remot another access channel comes on, the host is interviewing transsexual.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s time you went to sleep, Colonel --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: At ease, son. Charlie watches Slade "watching" television. He reaches f light switch, gently turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (softly) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Shush, this is fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie wakes up, hears a CLICKING sound from the directi Slade’s room. CLICK-CLICK, the sound repeats itself, then repeats itself again, it is unearthly in the dark of the morning, like some creature from another planet. Charlie gets up, opens the door between the rooms, the li from his room barely illuminates Slade who is sitting in chair, a side table pulled up in front of him. The extra blanket from his bed is folded in half over the table.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You got a watch? Charlie looks at the clock besides Slade’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask the time, I want to know whether you got a watch?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. In my roon.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Get it. Charlie hesitates, another CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: LIE
dialogues.text: There’s a clock right beside your bed, Colonel --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Does it have a second hand?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Time me. Charlie switches on the light, Slade is holding a .45 in hand. Slade signals Charlie to start timing him, in what like an instant Slade has dismantled the gun, every part out and is laid in perfect position on the blanket in fro him, just as quickly he reassembles it, cocks it, dry-fir SLADE (contd) How long? Charlie hesitates, decides to go along.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (checking Slade’s bedside clock) 49 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I‘’m rusty. He starts to take the pistol apart again, slowly, feeling parts, taking a lot of pleasure in the process.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’d you get the gun, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Piece or weapon, Charlie, never a gun.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where’d you get the piece?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m an officer in the United States Army, this is my sidearm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re not an officer anymore -~

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So I’m retired, so what? An officer never relinquishes his .45.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: you better relinquish it to_me or I’m going to have to call Mrs. Rossi.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And then I’m going back to school.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Blue skies, green lights, I hope you have a wonderful trip. CLICK, CLICK, Slade has reassembled the pistol in rapid t SLADE (contd) That felt like 45 seconds. You should be able to do a .45 in 45. Did you time me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I did not. And I’m calling Albany. He searches in his pathetic wallet, finds Karen’s slip of carefully unfolds it when suddenly Slade, quick as a cat, snatched it out of his hand, balled up the piece of paper swallowed it. Charlie regards him, Slade’s Adam’s apple still bobbing. CHARLIE (contd) That was stupid.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re stuck with me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not, I’m out of here.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: How? All the way to New Hampshire on no money? Ever hitchhiked on the West Side Highway? You’ll end up hog-tied in a dumpster in Hackensack.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t scare me.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You scare me, Charlie. (sings) ‘Charlie, my boy Oh, Charlie, my boy You thrill me, you chill me With shivers of joy...’ SNAP, Slade has taken apart the .45 again, his fingers ar a watchmaker’s with the gun.

SLADE (contd) (rubbing his stomach) Karen’s number tastes like Albany. (tilts his head) I’m headed for Arlington, Charlie. I got my plot all picked out, section 46, next to Audie Murphy’s. They may give you a hard time because The Unknown Soldier area is high-rent, but be firm, tell them I qualify on every count -- 100% disability, Silver Star, 20-year man, active duty, authentic Purple Heart. CLICK-CLICK, Slade has reassembled the pistol, Charlie re for it, Slade extends the pistol at arm’s length, out of Charlie’s grasp. SLADE (contd) If they give you a hard time on Section 46, ask for a space near Joe Louis’ or Abner Doubleday’s. I always liked baseball.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Give me the gun, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: An officer never gives up his sidearm, I told you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: In that case, I’m leaving. Charlie takes a step towards his room.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie! Charlie stops. SLADE (contd) (carefully) All I want from you is another day. - Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: For what? Slade throws up his hands spontaneously.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: One last tour of the battlefield. I can get around in a big city like New York but now and then, I need a point in the right direction. What’s a day between friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment. He tilts his 75.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Say I stay for another day, will you give me your weapon?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m a Lieutenant-Colonel in the United States Army and I’m not giving my fucking gun to anybody. What are you drinking? flask, takes a huge swallow.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel, this is unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘unacceptable?!’ Don’t give me any of that prep school crap. Have they already taken the Oregon out of the boy and turned it into Harvard Business School? Slade cackles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, give me the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: My ammo?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You want to be next to Joe Louis or not?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You do see the sense of it, Charlie, don’t you? I can’t chew the leather anymore. So why should I share in the tribe’s provisions?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (firmly) The bullets, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘The bullets, Colonel.’ You sound like a guy in ‘Lives of a Bengal Lancer.’ Next thing you'll be asking for my blindfold and cigarette. CLICK, CLICK, Slade removes the magazine, flips it to Cha he catches it. SLADE (contd) What do you give a shit for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade stands 76.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: LADE
dialogues.text: About whether I blow my brains out or not.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because I have a conscience.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I forgot. The ‘Charlie’ conscience. Do we tell or do we not tell? Do we follow the rich boy’s code or not? Do we let the blind asshole check out? When were you born, Charlie, at The Round Table? Haven’t you heard, conscience is dead?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t heard.

dialogues.speaker: THEN TAKE THE WAX OUT OF YOUR EARS AND
dialogues.text: GROW UP! Fuck your buddy, cheat on your wife, call your mother on Mother’s Day. It’s all shit. up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: To take a leak. I know I said only a day, but even I can’t hold it that long. The phone RINGS, Charlie answers it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hello. (to Slade) It’s for you -- Manny... Slade doesn’t respond. CHARLIE (contd) ...the limo driver. Slade takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Colonel Slade...yes, Manny...Fifth Avenue?..-really?...all right, give her my name, tell her she’1ll be hearing from me...no, no special needs...you did good, hombre.  50

He hangs up. SLADE (contd) Get dressed -- the battlefield awaits. Slade turns towards the bathroom. SLADE (contd) And Charlie...you forgot the one in the chamber. Slade instantly cocks and uncocks the pistol, expelling t bullet, which tumbles in a harmless arc, landing at Charl feet. Slade spins his .45 cowboy-style, drops it into his bathrobe pocket and disappears into the bathroon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Manicurist works on Slade’s fingernails, a Bootblack do Shoes while a Barber gives him a shave. Charlie paces in narrow alley behind the ornate chair.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ...No haircut, Charlie? Take a shave. Let this old pro loose on your peach fuzz, you’ll feel like a new man.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No shave, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Barber) I’m trying to get him laid. The Bootblack finishes Slade’s shine with a flourish.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Bootblack) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTBLACK
dialogues.text: These are good shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) You hear that? (to Bootblack) Twenty-six years in the service, I never let an aide shine my shoes. He senses Charlie pacing behind hin. : SLADE (contd) Where will you be in twenty-six years, Charlie? Playing golf, 1/11 bet, with those friends of yours from The Baird School.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t even like those guys.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Of course you don’t. They’re assholes. “It’1ll be a pleasure to squeal.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m not a squealer.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What is this, The Dreyfus Case? Refresh my memory. You and, what's the other guy’s name again -~ ?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: George Willis.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You and George Willis saw who do what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Harry Havemeyer and two of his buddies pour concrete into Dean Trask’s Jaguar.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good grief! Vanden Plas or a J6? A nonplussed Charlie doesn’t answer. SLADE (contd) Never mind, are you worried that Harry Havemeyer’s going to get the boot? Not with a name like that. Slade, whose shave is finished, stands up, wipes his face with the barber sheet. A moody silence surrounds Charlie. SLADE (contd) I’m getting that heavy feeling again, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade strides along, his hand resting on Charlie’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ...I was offered a bribe. ~

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Now we’re cooking.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dean Trask said he would see to it that I got into Harvard --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: If you squeal?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What a dilemma. Should Charlie Simms accept a free ride into Harvard or not? What do you think your friend George would do if he were in your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He is, practically. Except the Dean hasn’t promised to get him into Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have to. George’s father will take care of that. (a moment) Do the deal, Charlie. Take it. Go to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can’t do that. Slade stops.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There are some things you can’t do.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie, my boy, you’re going to have a hard time in this world. (a moment) To soften the blow, let me buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . The lush atmosphere of an ornate public room, tea table gilt chairs, palm fronds and ficus trees surround a dance The chatter of a sophisticated New York crowd mingles wit music of an elegant trio. A Waiter is taking Slade’s orde drinks. *

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Double Jack Daniels on the rocks. Bring the young man a Shirley Temple.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not so fast. (to Waiter) You got beer?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes. Can I see some I.D.? Slade raises his cane to the Waiter.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Interested in walking the rest of your life, Chappie?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Sir, I --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m a regular here. My boy’s going on twenty-three. Speak to Mr. Gilbert in the front office, he’s a friend of mine. The Waiter weighs the situation.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Any particular beer?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Schlitz. No Schlitz, Blatz. The Waiter goes, Slade punches Charlie on the shoulder. . SLADE (contd) You’re human. (peering around) Who are we drinking with? I’m getting a nice, soap-and-water feeling next to us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Female.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Female!’ Hey! (cackles) If you’re calling her ‘female,’ you must like her or you wouldn’t be playing it so casual. Chestnut hair?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Brown.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What am I, a guy at a carnival? Slade drills Charlie with his blind stare.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The day we stop looking, Charlie, is the day we are dead. (after a moment) Move. where? CHARLIE ere?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You know where. Slade gets up, chuckling excitedly. SLADE (contd) Charlie, this girl was made for you. God-dam beautiful, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Bingo! The boy’s alive. In fact, DONNA, the young woman at the adjacent table, is knockout. SLADE (contd) (nudging Charlie) c'mon, son, perambulate, perambulate! Charlie, embarrassed, gets up and steers Slade towards Do Hiding behind Slade, Charlie does a weird balancing act b being present and not being present. SLADE (contd) (to Donna) Excuse me, senorita, could we join you? Donna takes in this pair, the stunning, blind, middle-age and his young, awkward companion.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Well, I am expecting somebody.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: He’s here? DONNA . No, but any minute --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, ‘any minute.’ What are you doing right now?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (smiles) I’m waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So you don’t mind if we wait with you? Donna smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No. Slade has already pulled up a chair. He sits down, Charli joins him as Slade leans into Donna.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You smell like a bar of Ogilvie Sisters soap. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That’s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good, I’m in the amazing business.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It is Ogilvie Sisters soap. (to Charlie) Granny gave me three bars for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m crazy about your grandmother. And I think she would have liked Charlie, too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Donna) Don’t pay any attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hi Donna, I’m Frank and...

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That’s Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) She likes you. Donna laughs, she is looking right at Charlie now. 82.
SLADE (contd) (seductively) What’s that music?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Samba. Or is it a tango? Donna’s shoulders sway gently.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s a tango. You tango, Donna?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I love to. But --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Michael doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘Michael,’ who you’re waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Michael thinks the tango’s hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Tell Michael I think he’s hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Donna) Don’t pay any attention to him. Or did I say that already? Donna giggles.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You know the name of this tango?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Tangos have names?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Of course, this one’s called La Punalada. Slade’s Spanish is perfect. SLADE (contd) ~ You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ‘The Stab.’ Donna risks another look at Charlie.

: SLADE (contd) Would you like to dance? Donna checks with Charlie, he gives a reassuring nod and, this moment, endears himself to Donna completely. Slade a Donna rise. SLADE (contd) (to Donna) Your arm? Slade takes Donna’s arn. SLADE (contd) I need some coordinates here, Charlie. Charlie leans into Slade.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're looking at about forty by twenty. You/re facing the long end. Halfway down on the left there’s a palm plant sticking out, on the right side’s the band -- Slade puts up his hand to tacit Charlie, hands him his ca He moves out to the dance floor with Donna, she raises he he takes hold of them, and in an instant they are into a Slade is a marvelous dancer, he moves in perfect consonan the music, at first it is all Donna can do to keep up wit put he leads so brilliantly, after a while she becomes a partner. The little trio is into the number now, the danc floor clearing for Slade and Donna, the tempo speeds up, rivulets of sweat run down Donna’s cheek but the Colonel cool and precise and in command. As Donna dances, her eye meeting Charlie’s eyes when suddenly, with a great glissa the tango ends and the trio takes a brief break but first and the customers at the tables, applaud. Donna leads Slade back to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Frank, you are one incredible dancer.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Wait ‘til you see Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s a liar, I don’t dance.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Donna) Isn’t he a charmer? Truth is, not only can he dance, he can sing you a helluva tune.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: La Punalada.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The stab. Silence, Charlie looks from Slade to Donna and back again MICHAEL, an attractive young man, approaches, he carries attache case.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Hey! They embrace. DONNA (contd) This is Frank and this is Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hi Frank, hi Charlie. (to Donna) Sorry I’m late --

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That’s okay, these two guys entertained me. I got to tell you, the time flew.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Michael) Your girl does a helluva tango.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (to Donna) At last. You found someone to tango with. (smiling, to Charlie) Let me shake your hand. He pumps Charlie’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No, no, it was Frank --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What the hell, I’11 shake both your hands. Michael pumps Slade’s ‘and Charlie’s hands. MICHAEL (contd) Honey, this looks like ‘the place,’ but we got a date with Darryl and Carol in the village.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Okay, okay -~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 86. Michael reaches in his pocket to pay the check, his chang jingles.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Take your hand out of your pocket, Michael, I/’11 get this.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why thank you. Donna kisses Frank, and now she kisses Charlie. Then sudd she hurries away. MICHAEL (contd) ‘Bye, guys. And Donna and Michael are gone. Charlie watches them disa as Slade stares in the direction where Michael last stood

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (emptily) ‘Darryl and Carol.’ INT. P.J. CLARKE’S, THIRD AVENUE - NIGHT : 53 Slade and Charlie are perched at the bar, drinking, and e cheeseburgers. They are like the eye of a storm in an exc holiday crowd, junior executives, male and female sizing other up, some already coupled.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Soap, for Christ’s sake! Twenty-two years old and she smells of soap and water! God, that’s a once ina lifetime thing and what happened? You blew it!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Blew what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That girl was crazy about you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me? She was getting ready to have kittens with you on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s the point. She was coming on to me but it was you who she wanted. x It’s the oldest trick in the world.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think you’re wrong. It was you that she liked. And you know she liked you, you just don’t want to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Watch it, I/’11 do the mind-fucking around here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We should have all gone to dinner. Then you and Donna could have snuck off and danced the night away.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You tell me. Slade summons the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Triple Jack Daniels, and another beer for the professor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’ve moved up to ‘professor’.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s for the cretin behind the bar. I don’t want him worrying about the Beverage Commission. (a final bite) This is my last cheeseburger.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That bad, huh? Slade smiles at Charlie’s attempt at a joke.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I feel like eating it all over again.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let's get you one, 1/11 spring for it.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Charlie, I’m full. But I’m empty, if you know what I mean. The bartender serves up the new round of drinks. SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) Ever hear that song of Frank Sinatra’s, ‘My Way?’ Charlie nods, sings a little bit of it. SLADE (contd) I hate that song. Charlie smiles.  88. SLADE (contd) I did it my way but my way’s no fucking good. (a moment) You won’t make the same mistakes I did, will you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I don’t have a way yet.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, you do. You’re a giver, Charlie. A helper. A reacher-out. Very valuable --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Great with women. They love that stuff. If I’d understood women, I could’ve ruled the world.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Donna sure went for you.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Maybe. The truth is, Charlie, with women I didn’t wear well. But that’s nothing against women. Men felt the same way.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think you’re being hard on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Isn’t it about time?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Everybody’s got problems. It’s how you work them out. You’re a marvelous man and you got a lot to offer --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t blow smoke up my ass, you’ll ruin my autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your reasons for killing yourself are invalid, Colonel. I’d love to ‘tear a herring’ with you and I/1l bet there’s plenty others standing in line behind me -- if you’d only give us a chance. Slade stares at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I got a phone, Charlie. In the last two months I received one call. They were trying to sell me The Boston Globe. I decided against it. But TI enjoyed talking to then. Charlie regards Slade, Slade senses him, reaches out, rum Charlie’s hair a little too roughly. SLADE (contd) The head is slightly underdeveloped. Oregon out of the Boy Scouts by Mom’s Apple Pie. Slade’s hand falls to Charlie’s chest. SLADE (contd) But you know something, Charlie my boy, in parts your heart is good. Play it smart. Give a little now and then so you can get what you want.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sell out?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: In installments. To the highest bidder. Charlie switches drinks with Slade, swaps his beer for Sl shot of Jack Daniels. Takes a sip, winces.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don’t believe a word of that. Slade smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: All that stuff about squealing and running for cover and doing the deal -- that was all bullshit, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yes. Charlie drains the Jack Daniels, exhales at the strength drink. Slade, for the moment, has fallen silent. SLADE (contd) I used to come here with Big Ed for brandies after ‘21’. We’d sit in the pack over there -~ Charlie looks around, plugs into the charged atmosphere o paired-off singles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 90. SLADE (contd) We never went home alone. Things were different then, Charlie. After a sudden and deep silence, Slade turns to a woman o eft. > SLADE (contd) Dance? The woman, frightened, swivels away. SLADE (contd) No? Slade sits for a moment, then steps off his barstool, dri towards a dark, empty area next to the jukebox, and dance alone. He moves like a sylph and Charlie, for the instant gives himself up to Slade, enjoys it. Suddenly, Slade calls to Charlie. SLADE (contd) Get a hold of Manny. Tell him ‘now’. Slade is staring blindly but intently at Charlie and it i until Charlie crosses to a pay phone, that he resumes dan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade and Charlie are seated in the back of the limo, it parked in the east 60’s just off 5th Avenue, Manny at the the lights out. Charlie is peering through the limo windo brownstone down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’d say it’s about twenty steps --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yards. Always give it to me in yards, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: About fifteen yards, and there’s stairs --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: A stoop. How many? CHARLIE “ one, two, three...looks like nine.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Nine steps up. Railing?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No railing.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Bell?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There’s a shiny, brass plate on the right, about shoulder high.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: How do you know it’s not the mailbox?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This mailbox has got an ivory button in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good work. Slade leans towards Charlie. SLADE (contd) How’s my part? Charlie checks Slade’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Straight as an arrow. Slade fluffs up his pocket handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I got the red foulard okay, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Real dark red --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Burgundy! Burgundy, Charlie! They love it. Slade takes a deep breath, exhales, sniffs. SLADE (contd) (to himself) Bay Run. (adjusts his tie) Windsor knot. He swings open the door of the car and steps out. As he straightens himself up on the street, he turns back once Charlie, throws him a happy, mini-salute, walks on down t the brownstone. Manny and Charlie are tracking Slade as h moves unerringly to the bottom of the brownstone’s steps, them, rings the bell, a black woman in a formal maid’s un admits him, closes the burnished wood door. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: You know, Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Normally, I don’t do no whoring and pimping around for the customers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure you don’t, Manny. (after a moment) This your first time?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Well... Another moment. MANNY (contd) Maybe when I first purchased the car, I had this big balloon payment. But the Colonel, you know, Charlie --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: The Colonel is a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Class. Charlie weighs Manny’s sincerity, regards the burnished w door down the street. He reaches for the car phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can you get long distance on this?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: And how. Be my guest. Charlie unfolds a piece of hotel memo paper from his wall dials.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: George Willis, please. Hello? HARRY (V.0.) ello?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Harry?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Chas. You just caught us. We were chauffeuring George to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s he going to th e@ airport for?

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hold on, why don’t you talk to the man himself? Charlie waits. Chas...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You just caught me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s what Harry said. Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To Boston?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Catching the puddle-jumper. Keep your fingers crossed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why are you going home?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was thinking, Chas, this asshole Trask is making no sense at all. Somebody’s got to talk to him. My father’s class of '59

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Your father? I thought we were going to keep our parents out of this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This guy Trask’s out of control. Dad will bring him to his a major fundraiser, y

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t. senses. He’s ou know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Relax, he’ll get us off the hook, hey -- what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A quarter to ten. 93.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whoa, I gotta go. Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: See you Monday. ‘Bye. Charlie hangs up, slumps in the seat, stares at the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window of the car, Manny can be seen sound as his hat tilted over his eyes. : The door to the brownstone opens and Slade emerges, count the steps, makes a left turn up the street to the limo. C swings the car door open and Slade slides inside. He seem completely at peace. After a long silence:

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What a beautiful woman. Manny, awake now, smiles at Charlie in the rearview mirro Charlie nods, Manny starts up the car, Slade sinking into backseat, all afterglow and dreamy wondrousness as they d away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is watching television, Sally Jessy Raphael inter a couple. He checks his watch, opens the door to Slade’s Slade is fast asleep. Charlie edges towards him, touches shoulder, an eye opens.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You okay? Slade nods drowsily, but the eye closes. Charlie shakes h awake. : CHARLIE (contd) Wake up, Colonel. The eye opens again. Slade shakes his head irritably.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE -
dialogues.text: What is it? CHARLIE . It's afternoon, you’ve been sleeping all day.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I talked to George last night. His father’s a big-deal alumnus, he’s got a lot of clout. No response. CHARLIE (contd) He’s going to talk to the Dean. George thinks his father might be able to get us off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s what he said?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Watch the ‘us’ part. Slade turns over, away from Charlie. Charlie regards hin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Colonel, don’t you want to get out and do something?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ...See the Statue of Liberty, visit the Empire State Building -- do something. Slade’s one eye closes again, his head slumps back into t pillow. Charlie walks around to the other side of the bed rocks him, the eye opens.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What do you want, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, you’re making me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You've got last-day-of-combat jitters. Your tour of duty is almost over. Slade’s eye stares into the middle distance. SLADE (contd) My money belt’s under the mattress. Take out your plane ticket and four hundred dollars. Mustering-out pay plus airport-to-school taxi.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, no rush, Colonel, I can stay a while --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie, you already gave me a day and for that I’1l1 be eternally grateful. Right now, I have other plans. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (carefully) What other plans have you got?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: To die.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh no, Colonel, you’re not going to die today.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Much as I value your opinion, that is not your decision. Go away now and let me sleep. Charlie squats by the bed, speaks quietly into Slade’s ea

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let’s start over, Colonel. What do you feel like doing today? No response. CHARLIE (contd) Look at this. The sun is shining, it’s a beautiful day. Silence. CHARLIE (contd) We don’t want to sit around and molder in this hotel room, do we? More silence. CHARLIE (contd) Don’t be a party poop, Colonel Slade. Let’s get out of here, go for a ride. Slade’s eyelid flutters. CHARLIE (contd) Yeah, a ride. The sun is streaming in now, hitting Slade’s face, he see relax for a instant.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: A ride?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a wild ride. A lip-biting, bone-rattling, double-clutching, mother-fucking ride! Slade shrugs noncommittally at Charlie’s outburst, but a of a smile flickers over his face. Charlie catches it, hu his shoulders purposefully. CHARLIE (contd) A ride, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie leads Slade up the street. Charlie strides on purposefully, a passive Slade leaning on his arn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade stares distantly out the window into the busy stree Charlie, standing next to a gleaming car, is locked in conversation with Fred Bisco. Other salesmen are around t they watch bemusedly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: ...Yes, this is a valid Oregon driver’s license and yes, we let appropriate customers test drive the Testarossa. But 17-year-olds with a blind companion, that we don’t do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The Colonel is not my companion, I’m his.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: very nice. But this is a hundred and ninety thousand dollar piece of machinery, and I’m not letting it out this door. Charlie moves to another model.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How about this one?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: The 348 ts, same deal. I’m not letting an unaccompanied kid get behind the wheel of a hundred and thirteen thousand dollar piece of machinery. As Charlie moves on through the showroom with Fred, they within earshot of Slade.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (quietly) He will not be unaccompanied, I’11 be with him. I’m his father. Fred stops, turns back to Slade.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You’re his father? Fred looks from Charlie to Slade and back to Charlie agai FRED (contd) I got an idea. Why don’t I take Dad for a ride? Slade is at odds with himself, he remains oddly quiet and passive, but Fred is an irritation he can’t ignore.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s your quota, Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Quota?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: How many Ferraris you sold this month?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Uh --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The market’s down, isn’t it? These things are not exactly walking out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: The Ferrari is the finest piece of machinery sold in the automotive world.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do, sleep in it or sell it? Fred regards Slade.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Sir, I’d love to accommodate you but

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Do we close or not? This vehicle performs like I expect it to, you/’ll have a certified check for a hundred and four thousand and change when you open up tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: One hundred and thirteen thousand, eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Freddie, for you, one-oh-seven and a case of champagne. To go with your leftover turkey. Fred shifts, glances at Charlie who is inscrutable, now d his attention back to Slade.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Can you testify to your son’s driving ability?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: He got his learner's permit from Mario Andretti. Fred smiles, starts walking towards the drive-out area.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: ...35 miles an hour on city streets, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Not a revolution over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie emerges at the wheel of a Ferrari-red 348 ts, a t Slade in the seat beside him, orienting himself to the no raffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red bullet flies up the highway, MOVE IN on the Ferrari Charlie hunched over the wheel, the window on the passeng zips down, pointing the way with his cane now is Slade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuck in bumper-to-bumper traffic, Charlie raises the convertible top and he and Slade are now fully visible, S flourishing his cane, remonstrating with the driver of a semi. As the traffic releases past a bottleneck, Charlie up speed, the red lozenge of a car slips past everybody, the ramp, and onto the Harlem River Drive.

dialogues.speaker: INT, FERRARI
dialogues.text: Charlie is all business at the wheel. Slade’s head bobs i vacuum of ‘the windscreen, it is hard for him to suppress excitement. A big diesel horn is BLOWN at them and Slade his cane in acknowledgement. 59 66 61 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie picks his way expertly through traffic, under the Queensboro, down past Stuyvesant Town, and across the Bro Bridge. As the World Trade Center gleams in the backgroun Slade, like an oblivious child, starts to stand up in his but Charlie yanks him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warehouse area under the Brooklyn Bridge, the sun shini brightly on cobblestone streets deserted on this holiday weekend. The Ferrari is nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just take it easy, man.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is it clear...or is it clear?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wide open. The 348 ts now emerges from around the corner of a buildi Slade is at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Straight! Straight! The Colonel is beside himself with excitement. He picks u speed. CHARLIE (contd) For Christ sake, slow down, Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hold on, Charlie, I think we got another gear here -~- The car goes even faster.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL SLADE
dialogues.text: Slade, his shoulders rocking, is dancing with the Ferrari Charlie hides his head.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Now let’s see how this baby corners. Charlie straightens up. -

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Corners?!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Say when.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Say when, what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Say when to turn!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You can’t turn!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Where’s the turn? Two o’clock, three o’clock -- right oblique, right face, what?! Talk!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Three o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I knew it! Now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, not now! The empty intersections fly by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Please, Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m getting ready to take a corner. Here we go -~-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay -- wait-wait-wait -- Now!! Slade double-clutches very professionally, making a scree terrifying Grand Prix turn.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie, you’re riding with a very happy man. Charlie, frozen in his seat, cannot speak. And for the mo neither can Slade. He seems transported by the situation, completely open and totally vulnerable. SLADE (contd) Oh, I love this. * Then, in the very next instant, he is all himself again. SLADE (contd) Let’s take it to the max. Slade stands on the accelerator.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, jee-zus. The car hurtles down the empty warehouse street, the Ferr engine deafening, Charlie’s eyes wide with fright, Slade’ bared in ecstasy. CHARLIE (contd) Oh please, oh don’t, oh don’t -- Charlie is desperate, suddenly he hears a SOUND, he can’t identify it for a moment, it is Slade, screaming, he is . SCREAMING with delight, his hands clutching the vibrating Charlie goes white. CHARLIE (contd) Let me out. The SOUND of a police siren.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Shit, the yellow flag. And I hadn’t even opened her up yet. Slade, cackling, slows the car. SLADE (contd) Where’s the curb? CHARLIE (contd) Uh -- uh, one o’clock. Slade starts easing over. CHARLIE (contd) Easy, easy... The Ferrari bounces off the curb.

dialogues.speaker: BULLHORN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Pit stop. We’ll be out of here in seconds. A blue-and-white Traffic Division vehicle is right on the Ferrari’s tail. More BLIPS of a siren. SLADE (contd) * I haven’t had a ticket in years.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God -- Slade comes to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’11 do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade cuts the motor, lowers the window, looks right out PATROLMAN GORE, 28, an attractive example of New York’s f

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: License and registration. Charlie reaches across Slade and hands Gore a document fr glove compartment. GORE (contd) to Slade) Test-driving this baby?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t she purr, though?

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: At ninety miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Wait til you hear her at a hundred and twenty-five. Charlie slumps in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: Where’s your license?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: At the dealer’s. They give it back to you when you return the car. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: I.D.
dialogues.text: Slade reaches in his wallet, hands Gore a plastic card. H reads it very carefully. GORE (contd) Lieutenant-Colonel Slade? Slade snaps off a sharp salute.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: And you, soldier? Charlie groans.

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: The name is Patrolman Gore, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What outfit?

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: Traffic B.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re doing a helluva job, Gore.

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: And so are you. (nods at Charlie) Who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s my boy, Charlie. He kept telling me to let it out, what was I going to do, disappoint him?

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: Yes. Slade falls silent, so does Gore, who keeps checking the military I.D., then Slade. Slade has a choirboy’s express his face, as if waiting to receive his punishment. GORE (contd) I’m going to let you go Colonel Slade -- on one condition --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: You take this rig straight back to the dealer. .

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You got it!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Shut up. He turns back to Gore. SLADE (contd) Your face and your voice are familiar, Gore. You ever in the Officer’s Club in Dhanang? Charlie’s head sinks into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Never in the Army?

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: Coast Guard.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE '
dialogues.text: Good Lord. Gore contemplates Slade for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GORE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Your Dad’s looking good, Charlie, but he’s got a heavy foot. Tell him to lighten up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I hear you. Gore starts back towards his car. SLADE (contd) Gore! If you ever need a letter of commendation for your 201 File, let me know. I/11 write the Commandant. Slade revs up the Ferrari noisily.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Get out of that seat, you’re not driving anymore!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Just keeping this baby warm. As the blue-and-white police car drives away, Charlie jum of the Ferrari, runs over to the driver’s side, helps Sla hands him his cane, and Slade taps his way back to the pa side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred is waiting as Charlie pulls in with Slade. Fred chec car over, approaches Slade as he is helped out by Charlie

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I was afraid you guys took a powder to Passaic. Slade ignores him. FRED (contd) . So?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m crazy about the car.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: It’s another world, isn’t it?  106.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: We took her to the max and she sang like a dream.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (smiles) I ought to put you to work here on the floor, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: There’s only one thing wrong. Fred looks anxious. SLADE (contd) The color. Fred checks the car, now Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: The color?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I don’t like the color. Slade is staring blindly right at the 348 ts. FRED . You want silver, we’ll give you silver?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No, this is the car I want.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: This car is Ferrari red.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: \ I don’t like Ferrari red. It reminds i me of the G-2’s dick, you know what I mean, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Some other time.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE -
dialogues.text: (to Fred) Some other time. Slade takes Charlie’s arm now, and they calmly stroll out watches from the doorway as Charlie gives a piercing } two-fingered whistle, a cab materializes right out of t , hour traffic, they climb in and disappear down Park Ave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi is stuck in traffic, a classic New York city gri Slade jerks his head this way and that, tapping his foot impatiently, but there is no movement on the street, just HONKING of horns and the SHOUTS of taxi drivers. Charlie his impatience but Slade, uncharacteristically, says noth He is within himself. His sightless eyes blink agitatedly

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: This is taking too long. In an instant he has opened the door and stepped out into maelstrom of cars and pedestrians in midtown, his cane fl his antennae taking him with the flow, Charlie throws som at the taxi driver, jumps out, but Slade has already stro away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Colonel! C’mon, Colonel! The light changes, around Slade the traffic starts moving he continues on through it. SCREECHES of cars braking, ca and drivers yelling, Slade loses his cane but he is imper as he hurries along on his forced march, slamming into a can, taking a moment to knock the heavy thing into the st Charlie retrieves the cane, catches up. Slade has an odd to him, a film of sweat. CHARLIE (contd) What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’ve got to take a piss. He starts to undo his fly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel, for Chrissake, you’re on Park Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The perfect place. They are on the median of the street now, Charlie backs S against the fence, at the same time shields him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Button your fly, here comes a cop.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’ve got nothing to hide from the New York City police. CHARLIE . Please, Colonel -- zip it up!  108.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, Charlie, okay, don’t get excited. Slade has spun around now, zipped _up his fly, he reaches the fence, fumbles in the bed of Fall flowers planted in median, plucks a huge chrysanthemum. . SLADE (contd) Will you be my date for the Navy game, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Cut that out!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (sadly) ‘cut that out.’ Jack Benny used to say that. I loved Jack Benny. Gimme your arm, I’m getting tired. Slade seems to collapse for a moment, all his weight goin Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Promise me, you’1l never do anything like that again.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’d I do?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Run out in front of a whole bunch of cars.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What kind? Charlie hustles Slade through the revolving door of the W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade and Charlie move up the steps leading to the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Which way’s the men’s room?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We’ll be upstairs in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE -
dialogues.text: Okay, I’11 use a palm tree. They are in the lobby, and indeed the fronds of a palm tr brushing the Colonel’s face as he again undoes his fly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You do that, Colonel, and I’m going to leave you here.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s why they put palm trees in hotel lobbies, Charlie, to pee in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good-bye. Charlie releases Slade’s arm and walks away. Slade is bewildered for a moment, his head turns this way and that

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: People lower their newspapers, a Bellman notices him. Sla bursts with song: SLADE (contd) (sings) ‘I don’t want to walk without you, baby Walk without my arms about you, baby I thought the day you left me behind I’d take a stroll and get you right off my mind But now I find that...’ A plainclothes Security Man is closing in on Slade, Charl coming from the other direction, Jaime, a bag in hand, re the Security Man and something stops Charlie as Slade, beautifully dressed and as presentable as always, deliver song to the bustling Waldorf lobby. SLADE (contd) (sings) ‘I don’t want to walk without the sunshine Why’d you have to turn off all that sunshine Oh, Baby, please come back or you’1l break my heart for me ‘Cause I don’t want to walk without you Nosiree’. A stunned silence in the lobby, Jaime applauds, now someo else, it isn’t crazy or not crazy, just a polite round of applause and everybody goes back to their business as Cha resignedly approaches Slade.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Could we go upstairs now?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why not? ~

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You won’t piss until we get to the room?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The feeling’s passed.

He takes Charlie’s arm and they proceed to the bank of el amid murmurs of "That was very nice" and "You’ve got a sw voice" from the onlookers. They recede into the distance Slade marches and counts cadence straight into an elevato door opens. SLADE (contd) ‘G.I. beans and G.I. gravy Gee, I wish I joined the Navy Count off Three fo’ Count off One, two, three, fo’!’ Charlie hurries in after him, Slade reaches the back wall elevator, pivots and continues to march in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie fumbles with the key, Slade slumps against the Charlie turns the key and leads Slade inside, the door sl behind then.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Whew. Slade, standing in the tiny foyer leading to the sitting appears contradictorily quiet. CHARLIE (contd) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It sounds like a grunt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you want to go to the toilet?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to go in your room now?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No. Charlie is puzzled by the sudden lack of affect.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re sure you’re okay?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Slade leans against the wall, he seems strangely silent b intent.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How about some television?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. Charlie turns on the television, flips through channels, or no reaction from Slade, Charlie switches it off, check watch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think I’11 make a call.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Slade is fooling with his cane, testing the shape of the of a chair. Charlie pokes in his wallet, withdraws a smal address book. He locates a name, picks up the phone, dial

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hi, is George there? An unfamiliar VOICE answers. GEORGE’S FATHER (V.0.) Senior or junior? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Junior. who! his? GEORGE’S FATHER (V.0O.) o’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A friend of his from school. GEORGE’S FATHER (V.0O.) Well, George isn’t going to be talking to any of his friends from school right now. Charlie glances over at Slade who has been carefully list to the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh? GEORGE’S FATHER (V.0.) Good-bye. The CLICK of a careful hang-up, Charlie slowly puts down phone, Slade’s attention is centered on him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you looking at me?  71

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m blind, Charlie. They stand there in silence, “regarding each other. SLADE (contd) I’m going to take a nap. Too much fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good idea. Let’s get you into bed.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No, the couch. I like this couch here. He finds the couch, falls on it and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You okay, Colonel? Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Go down and get me some aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Aspirin? You got it. Charlie goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie emerges from the shop, clutching a little brown b catches sight of doors about to close on the facing eleva with a jump he just makes it inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie enters the suite, flipping the bottle of aspirin, Slade is no longer on the couch. Charlie hears movement i Slade’s bedroom, he walks in. Slade is partially dressed dress blues, knotting his tie, fastening his jacket. He looks great.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are we going someplace?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m taking a trip.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Slade ignores him, places his medals against his chest, d them for the simpler ribbons, Charlie is observing him cl CHARLIE (contd) .-.Colonel?

Slade pivots and as he pivots, his .45 becomes visible st to his side, he unholsters it, inserts a magazine, CLICK- Ejects the magazine, CLICK-CLICK, inserts it again. Manic Slade loads and unloads the gun, Charlie watching hin. CLICK-CLICK. CLICK-CLICK. CHARLIE (contd) (quietly) I thought we had a deal.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m welching. I’m a welcher, didn’t I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
