dialogues.text: What you did tell me was you gave me all the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You believe everything people tell you? Don’t you know, Sailor, no self-respecting officer is without ammunition for his sidearm -- (touches his hat) -- either in his hat band -- (clicks a heel) -- or in his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (grim) You could have fooled me.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: And I did. How, Charlie, are you going to survive in this world without me? Slade places the barrel of the gun at his own temple.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Give me that gun. Slade lowers the pistol, spins it Sammy Davis-style on hi finger, leaves it hanging. Charlie regards the gun dangli from Slade’s finger, takes a step towards it. Slade flips - again, the handle smacks into his palm and now the gun pointing straight at Charlie. CHARLIE (contd) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m going to shoot you, too. Your life is finished anyway. Your friend George is going to sing like a canary. And so will you. (MORE)
SLADE (contd) And once you’ve sung, Charlie my boy, you will take your place in The Long Gray Line of American Manhood. (a _ pause) And you will be through.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What makes you think I’m going to sing?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: The same thing that brought you to The Baird School from Appleknocker, Oregon. Ambition. You reek of it. Striving is the name of your game. You were on your way up, Charlie, you were going to sit at the Councils of the Mighty. But you would have had to sing before they’d let you pull up a chair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’d like to disagree with you, Colonel --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re not in a position to. I’ve got a loaded .45 and you’ve got pimples. I’m going to kill you because I can’t bear the thought of your selling out -- and don’t worry about death. Lives are not measured by their length. You've stuffed a lot into 17 years, Charlie, gobs more than I have in 49.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Put that gun down, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You giving me ultimatums? I give the ultimatums.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s all right. I stood up to everybody and everything because it made me feel important. You stand up because you mean it. You know, Charlie, I don’t know whether to shoot you or adopt you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not much of a choice, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t get cute with me.
He cocks his gun again. CLICK-CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Colonel, please -- Colonel, put it away.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Godammit, I asked you a question! Do you want me to adopt you or don’t you?! Charlie is speechless. SLADE (contd) You know, the spouse or unmarried child of those having at least twenty years of active service are also entitled to burial at Arlington?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Could we get off suicide? You’re just in a slump right now.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No slump, Charlie. I’m bad. Not bad, rotten.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You’re not bad, you’re just in pain.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you know about pain? You're a fucking little snail darter from the Pacific Northwest. Slade reaches for a cigar one-handed, lights it with his blows a smoke ring, aims the gun at the smoke ring, Charl steps towards him and Slade lowers the gun again and poin right at Charlie. SLADE (contd) This is no time to grow a dick, ny joy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Please put the gun away, Colonel... Charlie takes one more step towards Slade. Slade hesitate twirls the gun furiously, and suddenly it is pointing at head again.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Don’t move. . Charlie freezes.

SLADE (contd) I’m talking Parade Ground -- (shouts) -- Atten-shun!! Charlie is motionless, sweat at his hairline as Slade’s a work overtime, the place static with the electricity of h concentration. Charlie advances on Slade, who keeps the p trained on his own temple. SLADE (contd) Soldier, you were given an order.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Give me the gun, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Charlie, in five seconds I’m going to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want your gun, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Five -- four -- three -- two -- WHAP! Charlie, ducking under the electrical field and qui a cat, grabs the barrel of the gun, tries to wrest it awa the Colonel won’t give it up. They struggle, Charlie hold desperately, pulling the gun down towards himself but Sla won’t release it. The barrel of the gun is now pointed at Charlie’s stomach, he has both his hands around it, but t Colonel’s finger is still firmly on the trigger. SLADE (contd) Let go.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I won’t.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’re going to die like a dog, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do it! You want to do it? Do it! Do it! Only the sounds of their breathing now. CHARLIE (contd) ~ I’ll explode all over you. Pull the thing, you blind motherfucker. Charlie starts to hyperventilate, his breaths coming in t heaves, sweat running down his cheek. Slade is inches awa

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You smell.  117. j CHARLIE I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to die, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: . CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Give me one reason not to.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’ll give you two. You can dance a tango and drive a Ferrari better than anybody I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You’ve never seen anybody do either. He stares down at his gun. SLADE (contd) (noodling gently) *pid you ever have the feeling that you wanted to go Still have the feeling that you wanted to stay...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i Please, Colonel, give it to me. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You know how to handle a .45? Another moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Half as good as a .90. Slade hesitates for a moment, he manages a weak smile, re imperceptibly. Charlie looks down, finds Slade has releas gun, Charlie holds it awkwardly by the barrel. Slade gent reaches out, with one hand he flicks a lever, the magazin out of the gun, with the other hand Slade catches it’and smooth move, reaches up and deposits it in Charlie’s brea pocket. Now Slade turns away. SLADE . I could use a drink.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How about a cup of coffee? SLADE . i That’s too big a leap for me right now, Charlie. Maybe tomorrow. Mr. John Daniels, no water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie crosses to the mini-bar, and Slade listens to the comfortable sounds of Charlie fixing him a drink. Charlie the glass to him. Slade takes a gulp, makes a face. SLADE (contd) I said no water, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No water. They have strong ice at the Waldorf. Slade smiles, takes another sip. The RATTLE of a key in the door, the Night Maid,-an aging attractive Hispanic woman, enters.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT MAID
dialogues.text: Turn down your bed, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, thank you -- Slade sniffs the air, opens his arms invitingly.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What he means, senorita, is come right in. | The Night Maid smiles anxiously. Charlie removes a set towels from her arm, shows her out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (kindly) Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT MAID
dialogues.text: Yes sir, good night. She leaves, Slade is still sniffing the area, his teeth b in a ravenous smile.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Boy, have you got a one-track mind.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Is there anything else in the world, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not for you. x

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s so bad? Women are the essence of life. You know what’s kept me going all these years -- (MORE)
SLADE (contd) (hesitates) ...The thought that maybe one day I could have a woman’s arms wrapped around me -- and her legs -- wrapped around me -- and --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: And that she might still be there in the morning when I wake up -- the smell of her, all funky and warn... Slade is staring blindly into the remains of his watery d Charlie watching him closely, Slade oddly drifts away. SLADE (contd) I finally gave up on it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you’re making a mistake. I don’t know why you can’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (dazedly) Have what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know, when we get back to New Hampshire, I don’t know why you can’t find someone. You’re a good-looking guy...you’re a lot of fun...great to travel with...sensitive... compassionate -- Slade smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Are you fucking with me, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes. . Slade laughs. The telephone RINGS. CHARLIE (contd) (to Slade) You know, from now on you don’t have * to decide to kill yourself to come to New York and have a good time. Charlie picks up the RINGING telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 120. CHARLIE (contd) (into phone) Hold on. (to Slade) Do you? A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (phone) Yeah? Oh hi, Manny...The plane? What time does it leave? -- (checks his watch) Oh my God! (to Slade) We missed our plane!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Your plane, Charlie, my ticket was one-way. Charlie holds up his hand to Slade.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's okay, Manny says there’re shuttles on the hour till 9 o’clock. Slade ignores Charlie, rubs his sleeve on the patent leat visor of his dress hat, fits it to his head. He looks impressive.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No way, Charlie. Not the shuttle, not at any price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo is at the curb, Jaime adjusts Slade’s bag in the slams the lid shut, hurries around to hold the door for S Slade slaps him fondly on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hyman, I like the cut of your jib. He hands him some money.

dialogues.speaker: JAIME -
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Nada. Slade steps into the car, Charlie following after, Jaime the limo as Manny drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manny picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: New England Turnpike all the way, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Open ‘er up, Manolo. Slade stretches out his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo catching the reflection of iron oxide tollbooth as the car enters Westchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade takes out his flask, tries to drink, but it is empt Charlie passes him the remains of a bottle of water, Slad drains it. Charlie peers moodily out the window, Slade’s head tilts hin.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m getting that heavy feeling again, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Um -- (a moment) Ahh --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: One um -- one ahh --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: uUm...I think you were right about George and his father. Another moment.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: As soon as we get back, Dean Trask is * bringing us up in front of the whole school --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Putting your feet to the fire? CHARLIE og A special meeting of the Disciplinary Committee.  77

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: And you say what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ill think of something. Slade tries to get a last sip out of his flask. Charlie h him a fresh bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Why are you all alone with this? Where’s your father?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He left.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I thought it was a Mom-and-Pop store. Who’s the Pop?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: My stepfather.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Why isn’t he in on this? Charlie doesn’t answer. SLADE (contd) He’s no good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s okay. We just don’t get along.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because he’s an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: That’s all right. Every family’s got one nowadays. They drift into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo drives on, passing noisy semis and lonely night- cars. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade and Charlie are both asleep, a blanket covering the Slade wakes up, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: Worcester.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Keep rolling, Manny. Charlie, asleep, shivers. Slade takes the blanket off him and doubles it up on Charlie, now he settles himself ramrod-straight in the corner of the backseat, his dress rests on his knee, his eyes are closed, but an acute sens awareness about him, as if he could bounce awake in an in As if he were in a foxhole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A screen door keeps slamming as students pour out of the building, green book bags and bicycles, they make their w gravel paths to the Academy Building in the distance. The limousine pulls up and parks, a few of the students g at the tinted windows of the car as they pass. The limo d opens, Manny hands Charlie a plastic Waldorf-Astoria laun bag.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: -.-This it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He takes the bag, climbs out of the limo, turns back to S who is still seated in the car, his head tilted towards C A bell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: First bell. I just got time to shave. Slade extends a cigarette-sized roll of bills.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Three hundred dollars. A job well done. If you ever need references, Charlie, I’m your man. Charlie takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Manny) It’s 16 Water Street. Just over the bridge and --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: We’ll find it.  79 80
He holds out his hand. SLADE (contd) Good-bye, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Colonel. They shake. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Okay, Manny. Manny squeezes Charlie’s shoulder, Charlie ties the knot laundry bag tighter, then runs into his dormitory, dodgin students as they come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impressive assembly hall, portraits of founders and fo headmasters line the walls, the entire student body is se into long benches, century-old relics with initials of al long dead carved into the backs. The benches face a stage a podium. Charlie enters, the bell is RINGING steadily now, a Monit touches Charlie’s arm, motions him up the steps to the st where the members of the Student-Faculty Disciplinary Com are taking seats in wooden armchairs arranged in a semi-c Facing the Committee are a pair of elementary school-type Charlie notices George at one of the desks, but he is dep to see a distinguished-looking, gray-haired man seated be him, GEORGE WILLIS, SR. George, Jr., who appears to have in size next to his father, studiously avoids meeting Cha glance as Charlie takes his seat at the other desk. Mrs. Hunsaker is beside the podium with a note pad. A noisy ru and scraping of benches, the students rising as Dean Tras enters from a wing. Charlie, isolated at his desk, looks out, his eyes rove t of students’ faces in the great hall. Seated in their mid and side-by-side, are Harry, Trent and Jimmy. The bell st ringing as the last tardy students take their seats. Tras approaches the podium. TRASK . ..-I called an open meeting of this institution this morning because the incident that occurred this Tuesday last, describes an issue that concerns all of us...not an isolated case of (MORE)

TRASK (contd) vandalism, what happened is the symptom of the sickness of a society, a sickness which runs counter to the principles this school was founded on. A school among whose graduates, three have sat at the desk in the Oval Room of The White House. Baird men have run State Departments and investment houses, founded department stores and coached football teams, our alumni receive their bulletins in ashrams in India and in palaces in Jordan, we are, in fact, known around the world as the cradle of this country’s leadership. But today we are bleeding from disrespect. A door to the assembly hall SQUEAKS open and Manny, caugh a rabbit in headlights, appears. Awkwardly, he leads Slad the stage and into a chair next to a startled Charlie. Sl settles himself in as if he were right at home, Manny dep quickly as Trask looks Slade up and down, as do the other participants on the stage. The students on the back bench rise, to get a better view of this blind article who has arranged himself at the side of Charlie Simms. Slade leans over to a bewildered Charlie, speaks intently him, now Charlie turns Slade in the direction of George’s father, Slade tilts his head in his fashion, examining Ge Sr. with his antennae, but George, Sr. meets his gaze. TRASK (contd) Who is this, Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ummm -- ahh --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Trask) ‘This’ is Frank Slade, Lieutenant-Colonel, United States Army, retired. I’m here in place of Charlie’s parents.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: In loco parentis. ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trask blinks. SLADE (contd) They could not make the trip from Oregon today.  126.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: And what is your relationship to Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Is this a courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: The closest thing we could manage to it.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Then if we’re taking oaths, I’d like to swear a few people in. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: There are no oaths at Baird, we are all on our honor.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Larry and Franny Simms are old and dear friends of mine. They asked me to appear here today on Charlie’s behalf. Okay? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Happy to have you with us, Colonel. Trask turns towards the desk where George and his father seated. TRASK (contd) Mr. Willis? WILLIS, SR. Which Mr. Willis? Slade pokes Charlie with his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: George, Jr., sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK -
dialogues.text: You were in a position last Tuesday night to see who vandalized my car. Who was it? GEORGE . Well, I have an idea who it was.  127.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Not an ‘idea’, Mr. Willis, did you see or did you not see?

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn’t have my glasses on. George’s father stares at hin. GEORGE (contd) (quickly) I was in the library, I had on my reading glasses, and then I helped Simms close up and I started to put on my regular glasses but it was a real frosty night, right? So I started to clean them, then I heard this sound, but I never got a chance to put them on.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Whom, with your limited vision, did you see? George hesitates, his father puts his hand on his arm, wh purposefully to hin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: } (to Trask) Well, like I say, it was real blurry -- I mean I can’t see without my : glasses --

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: What did you see, Mr. Willis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean definitively?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Stop fencing with me, Mr. Willis, and tell me what you saw! George’s father drills George with another stare.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Now don’t hold me to this, but -- I mean no glasses, and it was dark and everything and --

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Mr. Willis?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Maybe Harry Havemeyer, Trent Potter and Jimmy Jameson.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: ‘Maybe’?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ballpark. Best guess.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Could you provide us with some detail?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, Charlie could tell you for sure, he was closer. Trask, finally, irritated by the interchange, turns to Ch

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: You don’t wear eyeglasses, do you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: With your untrammeled sight, whom did you see? A moment. From their seats in the middle of the assembly, Harry, Trent and Jimmy, very nervous now, await Charlie’s response. CHARLIE (contd) I saw something, but I couldn’t say who it was.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: All right, what was the ‘something’ you saw?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I couldn’t say.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: You ‘couldn’t say’? Or you wouldn’t say?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I -- I just couldn’t say. .

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Couldn't, wouldn’t, shouldn’t! Mr. Simms, you’re exhausting my patience and making a mockery of these proceedings. I am giving you one last j chance -- the consequences of your response will be dire. (MORE)
TRASK (contd) By ‘dire,’ Mr. Simms, I mean your future will be jeopardized -- ermanently. Now, for the last Pine -- what did you see last Tuesday night outside my house?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I saw somebody --

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) ‘I saw somebody.’ Good! And did you see their size and shape?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: And they were the size and shape of whom?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They were the size and shape of -- A very long moment. CHARLIE (contd) ..-most any Baird student. Slade is ecstatic. Harry, Trent and Jimmy sink back into seats and exhale with relief. Trask surveys the gathering: the student body. the Discip Committee, George, Jr. and George, Sr., and finally, Char Slade.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: I am left with no real witness. Mr. Willis’ testimony is not only vague, it is unsubstantiated. The substance I was looking for, Mr. Simms, was to come from you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Silence. CHARLIE (contd) I really am.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, too. Because you know what I’m going to do inasmuch as I can’t punish Mr. Havemeyer, Mr. Potter and Mr. Jameson -- and I won’t punish (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. 130. TRASK (Cont’d) Mr. Willis, he is the only party to this incident who is still worthy of calling himself~a Baird man -- I am going to expel you, Mr. Simms. You are a cover-up artist and you are a liar.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: But not a snitch.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think I will.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Mr. Slade --

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Please watch your language, Mr. Slade, you are in The Baird School, not a barracks. Mr. Simms, I’1ll give you one final opportunity to speak up --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms doesn’t want it. He doesn’t need to be labeled ‘still worthy of being a Baird man’. What’s your motto here? "Boys, inform on your classmates and you’1l save your hide, anything short of that and we’ll burn you at the stake"? Gentlemen, when the shit hits the fan, some guys run and some guys stay. Here’s Charlie -- facing the fire. And there’s George -- hiding in Big Daddy’s pocket. And what are you going to do, Dean Trask? Reward George -- and destroy Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Are you finished, Mr.Slade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m just warming up. I don’t care if William Howard Taft or William Jennings Bryan went here, their spirit is dead. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLADE (contd) You’re building a ratship, a vessel for seagoing snitches, and if you think you're preparing these minnows for manhood, think again because you’re killing the very spirit this institution proclaims it instills. What a performance. The only class in the act is sitting next to me and I’m here to tell you his soul is intact. You know why? Because someone, I’m not going to say who, offered to buy it. Slade stares at Trask. SLADE (contd) However, Charlie wasn’t selling.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Sir, you’re out of order.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: You don’t know what ‘out of order’ is. I’d show you out of order, but I’m too old, too tired and too blind. If I were the man I was five years ago, I’d put a flame thrower to this place. I’ve been around, Dean-O, there was a time when I could see, and I’ve seen arms torn out and legs ripped off but there’s nothing like the sight of an amputated spirit -- no prosthetic for that. You think you’re merely sending this splendid foot soldier back to Oregon with his tail between his legs. But I say you’re executing his soul. And on what rap -- that he’s not a Baird man? Slade surveys the hall. Harry, Trent and Jimmy are all attention, enjoying the drift of Slade’s words. SLADE (contd) Baird men? You’ll be Baird bums. The whole bunch of you. And Harry, Trent and Jimmy, wherever you are out there, fuck you too. Harry, Trent and Jimmy go white. A rustle around them, ev few suppressed laughs. .

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: Stand down, Mr. Slade.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: I’m not finished. As I came in, I heard the words ‘cradle of leadership’. Well, when the bough breaks, the cradle will fall. And it’s fallen here.

Slade turns to the members of the Disciplinary Committee. SLADE (contd) Makers of men, creators of leaders, be careful what kind of leaders you’re producing here. Which youth do you think the young Tom Jefferson was like? Which young man do you think young Abraham Lincoln resembled? Who here takes after George Patton? He tilts his head towards George. SLADE (contd) This creep... He turns towards Charlie. SLADE (contd) Or Charlie? Slade turns towards his chair. SLADE (contd) I’ve come to crossroads in my life. I always knew what the right path was. But I never took it because it was too hard. Charlie’s come to a crossroads. And he’s chosen the right path. The path is made of Principle and it leads to Character. Let him continue on his journey. He sits. The hall is engulfed in silence. The SOUND of a hand clap from a back bench, two other han and now rhythmic applause starts, Trask is banging on a g but no one will listen, Mrs. Hunsaker is trying to quiet down, George Willis, Sr. turns beet-red, Harry, Trent and don’t know which way to turn, the members of the Student- Disciplinary Committee have already begun conferring, the CLAPPING builds and envelops the place, the old red brick building seems to shake with SOUND, Slade reaches down an squeezes Charlie’s arm, a wink from his gimpy eye. SLADE (contd) (to Charlie) How’s that for cornball? Trask BANGS his gavel insistently, now he stands up on th and crisscrosses his arms desperately, finally a reluctan SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: TRASK
dialogues.text: We will adjourn and the Disciplinary Committee will take this matter under advisement -- in camera -- in closed session --  133. A BUZZ, the Student-Faculty Disciplinary Committee member are still huddled, break from it. A Senior faculty member hurries over to Trask, speaks to him. Trask reacts angril faculty member holds his ground, Trask stalks off in a hu faculty member then hands a piece of paper to Mrs. Hunsak

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUNSAKER
dialogues.text: (reading) The joint Student-Faculty Disciplinary Committee need no further sessions, they have come to a decision. Messrs. Havemeyer, Potter and Jameson are placed on probation for suspicion of ungentlemanly conduct -- It is further recommended that Mr. George Willis, Jr. receive neither recognition, nor commendation, for his cooperation -- George, Sr. gets up and walks out. MRS. HUNSAKER (contd) Mr. Charles Simms is excused from any further response to this incident. The place erupts, RHYTHMIC APPLAUSE again, the back-bench climbing on each others’ shoulders to get a better view o Slade and Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) We better get off before they give us the hook. Slade takes Charlie’s arm, Charlie leads him out, Slade s as he goes: SLADE (contd) (to Charlie, over the

dialogues.speaker: NOISE
dialogues.text: No ginch, not a trace of a scent. When is this school going to enter the 20th Century?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where did you get that ‘Larry and Franny’ stuff? Those aren’t my parents’ names.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Sound good, don’t they? ‘

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. And thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: For you know what.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Hey, I was just protecting myself. What’s going to happen to all of us if George and Harry are running the country in twenty years? There is a hubbub around Charlie and Slade as Charlie lea out, students calling to Slade, "Thank you, sir", "Good g sir", "Hey, your friend’s great, Charlie", but still they give the blind Slade a wide berth as he taps his cane in a bro Emerging from the crowd, CHRISTINE DOWNES, 30-ish, a teac whom we have seen sitting with the faculty, calls out. Slade stops,

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Colonel! sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Did I speak too soon? (sniffs again; to Charlie) Ginch, after all.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: I’m Christine Downes, Colonel Slade, I teach Political Science. I just wanted to tell you how much I appreciate your coming here and speaking your- mind.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, are you married?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Uh -- uh, I -- uh --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Went to Artillery School at Fort Sill with a Mickey Downes. Thought he might have snagged you. Charlie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: No -- no -~ I’m afraid not --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (quickly) Colonel Slade was on Lyndon Johnson’s . staff, Miss Downes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Were you? Fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: ---Let’s get together and talk politics sometime. (MORE)
SLADE (contd) (sniffs) Fleurs de Rocailles? Christine is startled.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Flowers from a brook. Christine, charmed, is taken with Slade.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Well, Miss Downes, I’1l know where to find you. (a moment) Charlie? Charlie offers Slade his arm, Slade takes it, and Charlie him through the doors and out to the street as Christine them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car makes its way down the street, into town and acro bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Slade are side-by-side in the back seat again is within himself, not depressed or exhilarated, almost r

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: +--I think I’1l take my brother to the Super Bowl next year. Charlie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up outside 16 Water Street, the distant SO Francine and Willie playing, Donny’s truck is in the driv Slade lowers his window, breathes in the smell of the pla

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Yaba daba doo. Manny rolls down the window between driver and passengers has prepared three drinks from a half-pint bottle of Jack Daniels, a fingerful in each glass, hands one to Slade, o Charlie, takes one himself.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: This one’s on me, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade nods his thanks to Manny and now Slade turns to Cha raises the whiskey glass to his glass eye and strikes it PING.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Here’s looking at you. They drain their drinks. Manny hops out, retrieves Slade’s bag from the trunk, han to Charlie who has helped Slade out, Slade peels off a fe hundreds, hands them to Manny who mutters great gratitude Slade gives Manny a good-bye squeeze on the shoulder. Charlie picks up Slade’s bag, holds out his arm for Slade SLADE (contd) No thanks, Charlie, I’1l take it from here. You go ahead, Manny will drop you off at your dorm. Come by before you go home for Christmas, we’ll have a little cheer. And if you feel like it, you’ll stay for dinner. Sometimes she cooks pot roast -- it’s almost edible.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Gee, that would be --

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Charlie. Slade takes his bag from Charlie, heads up towards the ho himself, Charlie climbs back in the limo, watches as Fran appears around a corner of the house on her tricycle, Wil riding behind her on the rear running-board. Francine bra sharply at the sight of Slade. . SLADE (contd) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCINE
dialogues.text: Taking a ride.

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: On the trike?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Me, too! -

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: (to Francine) Get off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCINE
dialogues.text: I will not!

dialogues.speaker: SLADE
dialogues.text: Get off, Francine, or I’11 whack you with this cane. Francine gets off, Slade drops his bag. SLADE (contd) Give me your hand. Francine hesitates. SLADE (contd) Your hand! Francine gives him her hand, with his other he feels for handlebars of the tricycle, now he hits it with his cane, jumps off in terror, Francine backs away. Slade drops the as he locat.s the handlebars, now he climbs gingerly on t seat, all bow-legged and awkward. He is half-on -- half-o SLADE (contd) C’mere, Francie. She moves to him cautiously, when she reaches him, he lif on to his lap, now he starts pedalling, very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ' WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slade stops, Willie climbs on the back, holds on to Slade grabbing his belt. Now Slade picks up the pace. Karen app at the kitchen window, Donny beside her, they watch, dumb the proceedings outside. Charlie observes from the back seat of the limo, Manny is to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie peers out the limo window at Slade running sprint ‘the tricycle, Francine and Willie hanging all over him, and Donny, in thrall, at the kitchen window. A smile spreads over Charlie’s face. GO OUT on the smile.
